title: In the first 100 days of his second term, Trump has cast aside key elements of his first term record
content: Between tariffs, taxes, and vaccines, the second version of Trump is rewriting core parts of the policy enacted by the first version.
resumen:
In the first 100 days of his second term, President Donald Trump has taken steps to cast aside key aspects of his own first term.

Trump put major strain on the U.S.-Canada-Mexico free trade agreement (USMCA) by threatening Canada and Mexico with 25 percent tariffs. Trade analysts say the health of the USMCA is very much in doubt. Joshua Meltzer, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said Trump "pulled it apart again."

Trump made clear he wanted to jettison the $10,000 cap on the deduction taxpayers can claim for paying state and local taxes (SALT). The cap helped pay for the 2017 tax cut law’s broader tax rate cuts. The cap is all but dead on arrival in its existing form.

Operation Warp Speed, the effort to get COVID-19 vaccines to the public within a year of the start of the pandemic, is another key first-term economic policy. Paul Offit, a leading pediatric vaccine expert at the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia, said the project was “the greatest accomplishment of his administration.” Trump has stopped taking credit for it. Robert F. Kennedy Jr., Trump’s health secretary, is reportedly considering removing the COVID vaccine from the recommended childhood immunization schedule.

Trump’s vow to slap painful new tariffs on Canada and Mexico, his reluctance to champion his own groundbreaking vaccine initiative, and his promise to restore a tax break he eliminated are all politically motivated.

The USMCA required the full alignment of three nations and the sign-off of Congress. The final deal largely extended the open, tariff-free trade regime that North America had used for decades.

In March, weeks into Trump’s second term, Canada and Mexico complained that he had violated the USMCA by threatening steep tariffs.

Mary Lovely, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics think tank, said Trump has "really torn up the USMCA" with respect to automotive trade and other areas.

The change limiting the SALT deduction to $10,000 for married couples helped raise billions of dollars a year to offset some of the lost revenue from tax cuts.

Andrew Lautz, associate director of economic policy at the Bipartisan Policy Center think tank, said eliminating or raising the SALT cap will make it harder to offset the lost revenue from extending and expanding the 2017 tax cuts. Axing the cap would cost about $1 trillion over 10 years, according to an estimate by the non-partisan Tax Foundation.

Operation Warp Speed was a $18 billion public-private initiative. In December 2020, Trump praised the “monumental national achievement” at hand.

Kennedy petitioned the federal government to revoke authorization for the vaccines in 2021.

Offit said he was encouraged that the FDA’s process for developing the new COVID vaccine for the upcoming fall is moving forward as expected. Kennedy previously said he plans to review the childhood immunization schedule.

A White House official said that no final decisions have been made yet.

Offit said removing COVID-19 from the childhood schedule would impede access to vaccines.

Trump has floated raising tax rates for the wealthiest Americans.

title: Trump offers auto, parts tariff relief as he visits Michigan
content: The proclamation came ahead of Trump's visit to Macomb County, home of many autoworkers, to mark his first 100 days in office.
resumen: President Donald Trump moved to prevent some tariffs from layering on imported vehicles and to reduce duties on imported auto parts for automakers building vehicles in the United States. The 25% tariffs on vehicles and certain auto parts will not be stacked on top of aluminum and steel tariffs — and tariffs on Canada and Mexico, according to an executive order Trump signed. He issued a proclamation granting automakers credit to offset 25% duties on imported auto parts that go into vehicles assembled in the United States. Trump said he signed an executive order to give partial tariff rebates to any company that assembles its cars right here in the U.S. He warned those who don't bring their manufacturing back to the country. White House and Commerce officials said the deal will offer the certainty the auto industry has requested on trade policy so companies can make investments to move parts production into the country and boost U.S. job creation. In late March, Trump signed a proclamation ordering 25% tariffs on fully imported vehicles coming into the United States that took effect April 3 and on more than 100 categories of auto parts. The 25% auto tariffs implemented under Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act will remain in place. They no longer will stack on top of the 25% tariffs on aluminum and steel that Trump signed earlier this year, retroactive to March 4. The vehicle levies won't stack on the 25% duties on goods from Canada and Mexico. Trump already granted the auto sector an exemption from the latter tariffs for vehicles and parts that comply with the U.S.-Mexico-Canada trade agreement he signed in 2020. Other tariffs — like the 20% on China instituted in response to concerns around the synthetic opioid drug trade — will remain stacked. The proclamation offers an offset on tariffs on automobile parts used in U.S.-assembled vehicles worth up to 3.75% of the manufacturer’s suggested retail price for one year. After that, the credit falls to 2.5% until May 2, 2027, after which there will be no offset. The offset is not a reimbursement, but a credit to reduce the tariff paid. If a manufacturer builds a car in the United States that has 85% U.S. or USMCA content, the manufacturer effectively will not owe tariffs on that vehicle’s production for the first year. The credit is only available to the final producer of the vehicle, not suppliers. Automakers can determine the parts to which they allocate the offset. Trump insisted that the auto tariffs would increase U.S. production, create well-paying manufacturing jobs and increase federal income to lower taxes and pay off national debt. Automotive executives, suppliers and analysts raised concerns that the tariffs would create supply-chain instability and result in increased vehicle prices, lowering demand for new cars, SUVs and trucks. Trump said he was looking at "help" for the auto industry to give companies "a little bit of time" to move manufacturing to the United States from elsewhere. In March, Trump had described the original auto tariffs as "permanent, 100%." An analysis from East Lansing's Anderson Economic Group consulting firm estimates a significant benefit from a credit on imported parts up to 3.75% of the wholesale price of a vehicle. For vehicles like a Chicago-built Ford Explorer SUV that could see tariffs of $2,500 to $4,000, the move might offer $900 in relief. For vehicles more vulnerable to tariffs, like a Texas-built GM pickup truck that might see $10,000 in added costs from tariffs, the relief could be closer to $2,000. The policy moves toward an environment that could result in encouraging the manufacturing of more vehicles in the United States and some additional manufacturing jobs in auto states. U.S. Rep. Haley Stevens, D-Birmingham, said it’s not enough relief for the autos. The American Automotive Policy Council, a lobbying group representing the Detroit Three automakers, said it would review the actions to assess how effectively they mitigate the impact of tariffs on U.S. automakers, the supply chain and consumers. American automakers Ford, GM, and Stellantis appreciate the administration’s clarification that tariffs will not be layered on top of the existing Section 232 tariffs on autos and auto parts. General Motors Co. CEO Mary Barra and Ford Motor Co. CEO Jim Farley welcomed relief measures on the tariffs and said that they would continue conversations with the administration to ensure support for a growing U.S. auto industry. Farley challenged rivals to match Ford's manufacturing ratio in America, where it builds 80% of the vehicles it sells in the country. Barra said the actions would level the playing field and allow GM to invest more in the U.S. economy. The Detroit automaker reported Tuesday $2.8 billion in net income in the first quarter. GM said adjusted pre-tax earnings in the first quarter hit close to $3.5 billion, and earnings per share of $2.78. Stellantis NV Chairman John Elkann praised the promise of relief for the industry. The revised tariff proclamation is an improvement over the stacked duties. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the deal comes after meetings between Trump and foreign and domestic vehicle producers. He's committed to bringing back auto production back to the U.S. He added that national and economic security remain motivating factors for pushing automakers — and companies from other manufacturing sectors — to reshore their production to the United States. Trump believes that "economic security is national security, and national security is economic security." title: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney's Record on Latin America
content: Carney is positioning himself as a counterpoint to Trump. What’s his history with USMCA, migration, Venezuela, climate financing, and more?
resumen:
Mark Carney will continue to lead Canada after his Liberal Party won federal elections on April 28, 2025. Carney has been serving as prime minister since March 14 after being elected to helm the Liberals following Justin Trudeau’s resignation in January. Before ascending to Canada’s leadership, Carney, an economist, served as the head central banker of both Canada (2008–2013) and England (2013–2020), as well as the UN Special Envoy for Climate Action and Finance (2020–2025).

In 2022, Canada exported $16.5 billion in goods to Latin America and imported $50.2 billion. It was also a source of foreign aid, providing just under $1 billion to the region from April 1, 2023 to March 31, 2024—about 10 percent of its total provisions.

Carney took office amid drastic changes in U.S. trade policy, including the imposition on tariffs on Canada and Mexico. In February, President Trump formalized his intention to implement 25 percent tariffs on both USCMA partners—as well as 10 percent tariffs on Canadian energy. Those tariffs were implemented on March 4. On March 6, he exempted goods covered by USMCA from these tariffs for one month, giving them an April 2 start date. Carney took office as prime minister on March 14, two days after Trump implemented aluminum and steel tariffs on Canada and other nations. Carney did not speak to Trump for the first two weeks of his tenure as prime minister. He did say on March 18 that Trump’s tariffs "called into the question the validity" of USMCA. On March 27, he called for a “broad renegotiation” of Canada’s trade relationship with the United States, just as Trump announced 25 percent tariffs on Canada's auto sector. On March 28, the two leaders spoke. The call, which included a moment where Trump brought up annexing Canada, did not result in a tariff delay. Carney said, “We can make progress in this situation, but this is different from the world of 1990 and the world of NAFTA and even the USMCA.”. Carney then spoke to Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum on April 1, the day before the start date for tariffs on USMCA products, to discuss increasing bilateral trade. On April 2, the Trump administration declared USMCA goods would continue to be exempt from tariffs. The next day, Carney announced a set of retaliatory measures to the U.S. tariffs on Canada’s auto industry. That included 25 percent tariffs on U.S. vehicles non-compliant with USMCA. The measures do not apply to vehicle parts, nor automotive content from Mexico. USMCA is due for formal review in July 2026.

There are around 945,000 Latin American and Caribbean migrants in Canada, according to the 2021 census. Many arrived from the English-speaking Caribbean (37.2 percent) and Haiti (10.6 percent), as well as Mexico (9.6 percent) and Colombia (8.5 percent). During an April 16 French-language debate, Prime Minister Carney was asked to speak on the rising numbers of Haitian asylum-seekers and migrants crossing into Quebec in 2025. Carney suggested that most asylum-seekers entering Canada from the United States should be sent back under the terms of the U.S.–Canada Safe Third Country agreement. In October 2024, Trudeau, Carney’s predecessor, unveiled plans to lower the annual cap on new permanent admissions from 500,000 to 365,000 by 2027 and to reduce the proportion of temporary residents, including those on employment and student visas, from 7.25 percent of the population to 5 percent.

During his time as governor of the Bank of England, the Venezuelan administration sought to retrieve over $1 billion of gold reserves held in the Bank of England. The Bank of England denied the administration’s request in January 2019. Officials at the Carney-led Bank of England fielded at least one meeting with Calixto Ortega and other authorities from the BCV in December 2018. Carney received communication from Juan Guaidó, a Venezuelan opposition figure who served as interim president (2019–2023), asking that he reject “the illegitimate transaction.” Then-U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and National Security Advisor John Bolton also reportedly lobbied the Bank of England to deny the Maduro administration’s request to access the gold.

As UN Special Envoy for Climate Action and Finance, Carney launched the Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero (GFANZ) in 2021. In 2023, at the UN Latin American and Caribbean Climate Week in Panama City, Carney launched GFANZ’s network in Latin America and the Caribbean. In February 2024, Carney attended the G20 in Sao Paulo where he participated in several events on financing climate finance in Brazil, including one with Brazilian Vice President Geraldo Alckmin. In October, he headlined an event launching Brazil’s Climate and Ecological Transformation Investment platform with Brazilian Finance Minister Fernando Haddad and Environmental Minister Marina Silva.

From 2020 to January of 2025, Carney worked at Brookfield. The firm has an extensive presence in Latin America with $57 billion of assets under management in South America alone, including holdings of ports and energy infrastructure. The mayor of Lima, Rafael López Aliaga, spoke out against Carney and Brookfield. In Brazil, Brookfield’s assets include over a quarter million hectares of land in the country.

title: With better trade deals and tax cuts, Trump can usher in an economic boom
content: If Trump’s brinksmanship gets our major trading partners to lower their existing tariffs, we could end up with freer trade than we had before.
resumen:
President Trump’s tariff battles have caused market turmoil, business disruption and a temporary loss of consumer confidence in the economy. If Trump’s brinksmanship gets our major trading partners to lower their existing tariffs, we could end up with freer trade than we had before. Trump has taken steps to promote prosperity here at home.

Making the Trump tax cuts permanent: Trump’s 2017 tax cut was an enormous driver of economic success. The average small business saw a 20% reduction in its tax rates, and the corporate rate fell from 35% to a below-average rate (now 21%), spurring investment and development. Middle-class families saved on average more than $2,000. The 2017 bill doubled the standard deduction. The share of taxes paid by the richest 1% of tax filers was 40% of the total before the tax cut took effect — and is 44% now. The cuts were set to sunset this year. Trump’s bill to make these tax cuts permanent has already passed its first hurdles in the House and Senate and will be on his desk for signature within the next two months. If Trump gets the corporate tax rate down to 15%, the US would have one of the lowest such rates in the world.

Slashing costly regulations: Trump has put an end to Biden’s regulatory assault, which cost the economy an additional $20,000 per family over four years. Trump’s “one-in-for-ten-out” deregulation rule has already saved $2,000 per family, for an estimated savings of about $180 billion so far over four years.

Replacing welfare with work: The labor force participation rate in March 2024 was just 62.7% — down from 66% 20 years ago. Trump has already started to create new rules requiring able-bodied adults to get a job, or begin a training program, to receive government welfare benefits.

Deploying America’s abundant resources: The US has more than $50 trillion of natural resources. Trump’s executive orders are opening up this treasure chest of resources — which could over time raise nearly $10 trillion for the federal government in higher royalties and other tax payments.

Eliminating federal waste and fraud and duplication: Biden’s $6 trillion spending spree pushed government outlays to 40% of our GDP. Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency and the Trump budget team have already identified hundreds of billions of dollars of waste, fraudulent payments, unspent funds and a $350 billion green energy slush fund that can be returned to the Treasury.

Enacting pro-growth immigration policies: Trump has cut illegal border entries by 94%. He wants to implement a merit-based system to select future legal immigrants. He also wants to auction “gold visas,” raising as much as $100 billion, for those who agree to create businesses and jobs in America.

Draining the swamp: Fewer than 10% of our 2.5 million federal workers were working full-time in the office under Biden. Trump has ordered them to show up for work, or be fired. He has already downsized the federal bureaucracy by more than 100,000 employees through buyouts and tougher performance standards.

My sources in the White House and in the hierarchies of Congress have outlined their master plan:

First, Trump announces to the world a major and credible trade deal breakthrough. He takes the stage with major trading partners and proclaims that, to restore global commerce, these nations have agreed to lower their tariffs on US goods in exchange for the suspension of US US tariff increases.

A few weeks later, Trump and Republican leaders in Congress announce the passage of a tax bill making the 2017 tax cuts permanent, retroactive to the start of the year, with a new lower business tax rate for good measure.

Finally, congressional Republicans put their petty disputes behind them and agree to a budget framework that cuts $2 to $4 trillion of waste, fraud and redundancy out of the $7 trillion budget over the next decade.

The stock market would surge, the dollar would soar and interest rates on 10-year Treasury bonds might retreat by a full percentage point or more.

Foreign leaders — including China’s Xi Jinping — must come to the rational conclusion that trade deals lowering unsustainable tariffs and non-tariff barriers are in everyone’s interest.

The financial chaos of the past two months has hurt the US for sure. But the pain has been even more severe in Beijing — where the economy is imploding — and in Europe.

Republicans have no choice but to cut the deficit and extend the tax cuts.

Consumer attitudes worsened more than expected in April, casting further gloom over the economy as President Donald Trump’s tariffs set off warnings of price increases and a possible recession, fresh data on Tuesday showed.

The reading of sour consumer sentiment marked the fifth consecutive month of decline, leaving the Conference Board gauge at its lowest level since the COVID-19 pandemic.

Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell this month joined a growing set of policymakers and analysts who’ve cautioned about a possible outcome that bodes poorly for consumers: accelerating price increases alongside a sluggish economy.

A slew of companies have already announced plans for price hikes in response to the tariffs, including bargain retailers Temu and Shein.

An across-the-board 10% tariff applies to nearly all imports, except for semi-conductors, pharmaceuticals and some other items. Those levies come on top of specialized tariffs on steel, aluminum and autos.

Even after the suspension of some tariffs, U.S. consumers face the highest average effective tariff rate since 1909, the Yale Budget Lab found.

Trump last week said that tariffs on China would "come down substantially." Days later, however, Trump urged Boeing to “default China” in response to a Chinese order that airlines reject deliveries of the U.S.-based aerospace company’s planes.

Despite flagging consumer sentiment and ongoing market turmoil, key measures of the economy remain fairly strong.

The unemployment rate stands at a historically low level and job growth remains robust, though it has slowed from previous highs. Meanwhile, inflation cooled in March, putting price increases well below a peak attained in 2022, data showed.

Speaking at the Economic Club of Chicago earlier this month, Powell acknowledged the “solid condition” of the U.S. economy, but he cautioned about signals of a potential slowdown. For instance, Powell noted a “sharp decline in sentiment” among businesses and households.

title: OPINION | Bandung to Belgrade and beyond: The juggernaut of Global South
content: India has launched several developmental programs espousing the ideals of the Bandung spirit and engages with Global South multilaterally and bilaterally ...
resumen: This year marks the 70th anniversary of the Asia-Africa Conference, also known as the Bandung Conference, held in Indonesia from April 18-24, 1955. The conference was initiated by India, Indonesia, Shri Lanka (Ceylon), Myanmar (Burma), and Pakistan, with 29 countries attending. The conference aimed to protect and promote the freedom of newly liberated countries in Asia and Africa, emphasizing peace for development and cooperation. Key leaders included Sukarno of Indonesia, Ne Win of Burma, Zhou Enlai of China, and Jawaharlal Nehru of India. The conference led to the birth of NAM in Belgrade in 1961 and G-77 in 1964. The spirit of Bandung permeates the Global South. The polarization of the world and trade wars have added salience to the Voice of Global South. Recent developments, such as the erosion of multilateralism and America’s unilateralism, have given resonance to the spirit of Bandung. Bandung espoused values like economic and cultural cooperation, human rights, self-determination, and peace promotion. These values are being tested in Ukraine and the Middle East. The resurrection of the Cold War in the form of a trade war underscores the salience of the spirit of Bandung. India has scaled down its engagement with NAM but has not abandoned it. External Affairs Minister Dr. S. Jaishankar participated in the NAM Lusaka Summit. China’s dominance in BRICS and SCO offers strategic space for India’s engagement with the world. India connects with the Global South through its Voice of Global South, which has held three virtual summits. India has launched developmental programs espousing the ideals of the Bandung spirit and engages with the Global South multilaterally and bilaterally. India’s ‘Vaccine Maitree’ during the pandemic in 2020-21 echoed the Bandung spirit. India’s collaboration with France in launching the International Solar Alliance is an example of North-South cooperation. Other initiatives include the Coalition of Disaster Resilient Infrastructure (CDRI) and the Global Biofuel Alliance. India’s developmental partnership, such as the Line of Credit, contrasts with China’s BRI projects. India has convened the Voice of Global South in a virtual mode three times and used its G-20 presidency to highlight concerns of the Global South. The initiative to enlist permanent membership to the African Union (AU) was a message to the Global South. A new division in the Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) could be created to oversee work related to the Global South. title: Trump’s 100-Day Report Card
content: Market chaos and economic uncertainty has been a feature of the president’s first few months back in office. DealBook breaks down the milestones, and what to expect next.
resumen:
When President Trump took office in January for his second term, business leaders anticipated an administration that would lower taxes, loosen regulations and open up deal-making. Instead, Wall Street got chaos. Under Trump, the S&P 500 has fallen about 8 percent, the worst performance for the first 100 days of a presidency since President Gerald Ford in 1974.

Trump will commemorate the occasion with a rally in Michigan this evening, and the White House is expected to announce relief on auto tariffs. General Motors on Tuesday pulled its full-year forecast as it reported first-quarter results.

Trump inherited a robust labor market, an enviably growing economy and a record-breaking stock market. Much of that has been scrambled by Trump’s trade war. His tariffs, the highest level in a century, have scrambled global supply chains and redrawn trade alliances, sapped business and consumer confidence and raised the odds of a recession. Investors now talk about the “sell America” trade. Trump’s handling of the economy, a longstanding strength, is weighing on his popularity, the latest Times/Siena College poll shows. Another potential hit: Amazon will reportedly begin spelling out the tariff cost in the final price of an item, according to Punchbowl News.

The next few weeks could be decisive. The toll of tariffs hasn’t yet shown up meaningfully in inflation, G.D.P. and jobs reports. That could change with new data due this week, putting the Fed in a prolonged limbo on interest rates. All eyes will be on trade deals. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said on Monday that an accord with India could be struck first. Still, an agreement with China, the biggest to come, looks far away.

Elon Musk set up the so-called Department of Government Efficiency, but has said he’ll spend less time in Washington after Trump’s 100th day in office. Musk dismissed a $100 billion A.I. initiative that was the president’s first major tech deal. Last week, Musk announced that he would spend less time in Washington starting in May. His initiative’s goal is to save about $150 billion, down from as much as $2 trillion.

Musk has:
*   Effectively dismantled the U.S. Agency for International Development, which employed 10,000 people.
*   Dismissed at least 1,200 employees at the National Institutes of Health and proposed cutting up to an estimated $5 billion in annual funding at the research agency.
*   Fired thousands of civilian workers in the Defense Department with the expectation of as many as 55,000 more cuts.
*   Helped cut what may amount to about a third of the I.R.S.’ work force via deferred resignations and layoffs.
*   Cut billions in spending in the U.S. Postal Service and plans to fire up to 10,000 people.

Musk’s group has eliminated more than 200,000 federal positions as of March, according to an estimate from the outplacement firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas. According to one analysis, Musk’s cuts will end up costing taxpayers $135 billion from lost productivity, re-hirings and paid leave for thousands.

In an explosive cabinet meeting, Musk blew up at Secretary of State Marco Rubio, accusing him of not doing enough to cut costs. Trump eventually defended Rubio, and set ground rules: Cabinet chiefs would run their departments, and Musk would be an adviser.

The administration is hunting for savings to offset the anticipated hit of extending the corporate tax cuts, which Congress is working on this week. Reductions to the federal work force could show up in Friday’s jobs report. Economists expect about 150,000 jobs to have been added in April, down sharply from 228,000 in March.

Harvard sued the Trump administration, fighting back against its threats to cut billions of dollars from the school’s research funding. Trump has taken aim at a handful of elite schools. Harvard last week became the first to sue the administration over the crackdown. The university received a list of more onerous demands, and its resistance may have helped spur a coalition of 400 university leaders to fight back. In response, the Trump administration froze $2.2 billion in grant funding and is weighing a revocation of Harvard’s tax-exempt status.

Trump has also attacked Big Law. He has issued executive orders to revoke security clearances for several law firms. Firms have split into two camps. Some, like Paul Weiss, negotiated deals with Trump that include hundreds of millions of dollars worth of pro bono work. Others, like Jenner & Block, have sued to block the orders. Both campaigns include efforts to stop D.E.I. programs. Trump’s demands on Harvard, for example, included “all preferences based on race, color, national origin.” Paul Weiss’s settlement required the firm to reiterate its commitment to “merits-based hiring, promotion and retention” and hire an outside expert to audit its recruitment practices.

Harvard’s lawsuit argues that the administration is seeking unconstitutional control over the university, and that it ignored due process. Two federal judges seemed receptive to arguments from two big law firms, Perkins Coie and WilmerHale, that the orders against them should be permanently blocked because they blatantly violated the Constitution.

Thrive Capital is raising about $1 billion in initial funding for Thrive Holdings. Thrive Holdings is essentially a kind of permanent capital vehicle. It’s a twist on an emerging trend in venture capital: investing in A.I. companies in more everyday sectors and using them to buy other businesses.

Among the most prominent of President Trump’s cabinet members is Howard Lutnick, the Wall Street chief who serves as his commerce secretary. Executives and foreign officials have described some of his proposals as zany or harmful. Within the department, employees say morale has plummeted, as the administration has piled on work and slashed hundreds of jobs.

title: Cepal dice que economía venezolana caerá 1,5 % este 2025
content: La Cepal dijo que la política arancelaria de Estados Unidos no solo afectará las exportaciones sino que tendrá efectos indirectos ...
resumen: La Comisión Económica para América Latina y el Caribe (Cepal) rebajó sus expectativas sobre el crecimiento económico para 2025, tras la nueva política arancelaria de Donald Trump, presidente de Estados Unidos. En su informe de estimaciones, que se dio a conocer este martes 29 de abril, también puso a la economía venezolana como una de las que tendrá un decrecimiento del Producto Interno Bruto (PIB), que estima caerá 1,5 %. Haití será la economía de América Latina y el Caribe con una mayor caída, que la Cepal calcula será de 2 %, mientras que Cuba se contraerá 0,5 % este año. Esperan un crecimiento en Argentina (5 %), República Dominicana (4,5 %), Costa Rica (3,6 %) y Paraguay (3,6 %). En el medio de la tabla se encuentran Guatemala (3,3 %), Honduras (3,2 %), Nicaragua (3,1 %), Panamá (3,1 %), Perú (3,1 %), Uruguay (2,6 %), Colombia (2,5 %), El Salvador (2,5 %), Chile (2,2 %) y Brasil (2 %). En la cola, pero aún con cifras positivas, están Bolivia (1,8 %), las islas del Caribe sin contar Guyana (1,8 %), Ecuador (1,5 %) y México (0,3 %). La Cepal explicó que los anuncios en materia de aranceles efectuados por parte de Estados Unidos no solo tienen efectos directos sobre las exportaciones de los países de la región a dicha economía, sino también efectos indirectos por la vía de una mayor volatilidad en los mercados financieros internacionales. La confrontación geoeconómica suscitada ha aumentado el riesgo de disrupciones graves en las cadenas de producción global y en los flujos del comercio internacional y ha provocado una revisión a la baja de las prospectivas de crecimiento a nivel global y, en especial, de los principales socios comerciales de la región: EE.UU. y China. Latinoamérica cerró 2023 y 2024 con un crecimiento del 2,3 %.

title: Pone EU a México en vigilancia prioritaria por piratería
content: La Oficina del Representante Comercial de Estados Unidos (USTR, por sus siglas en inglés) incluyó este martes a México en su lista de vigilancia prioritaria en materia de derechos de propiedad ...
resumen:
La Oficina del Representante Comercial de Estados Unidos (USTR) incluyó a México en su lista de vigilancia prioritaria en materia de derechos de propiedad intelectual.

La USTR trasladó a México de la lista de vigilancia a la lista de vigilancia prioritaria debido a importantes y persistentes preocupaciones sobre propiedad intelectual que no se han resuelto, muchas de las cuales se relacionan con la implementación por parte de México del Tratado entre Estados Unidos, México y Canadá (T-MEC).

Estas incluyen inquietudes sobre la aplicación de la ley contra la falsificación de marcas y la piratería de derechos de autor, la protección de la propiedad intelectual relacionada con productos farmacéuticos, los daños preestablecidos por infracción de derechos de autor y falsificación de marcas, y la protección de variedades vegetales.

El informe anual de la USTR incluye ahora a ocho países en su lista de vigilancia prioritaria por deficiencias y violaciones de los derechos de propiedad intelectual, y a 18 países en su lista de vigilancia.

Ocho países figuran en la lista de vigilancia prioritaria: Argentina, Chile, China, India, Indonesia, México, Rusia y Venezuela.

El Secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent, dijo el lunes que el Gobierno estaba en conversaciones con entre 15 y 18 socios comerciales clave sobre los fuertes aranceles estadounidenses anunciados por Trump el 2 de abril, pero suspendidos hasta el 8 de julio.

El Representante Comercial de Estados Unidos, Jamieson Greer, dijo que el informe exhaustivo es una base para que Estados Unidos tome medidas de aplicación comercial contra quienes no juegan limpio.

Trump aplicó aranceles de 25 por ciento a México en marzo por no detener las exportaciones de fentanilo.

La USTR mantuvo a China en la lista de vigilancia prioritaria.

El USTR retiró a Turkmenistán de la lista principal de vigilancia.

Vietnam y Brasil permanecieron en la lista de vigilancia regular.

title: República Dominicana espera que EE.UU. no demore respuesta sobre eliminación de aranceles
content: El Gobierno espera recibir en las "próximas semanas" o en los "próximos meses" una respuesta de las autoridades estadounidenses, a quienes propuso oficialmente la semana pasada eliminar el arancel del ...
resumen: El Gobierno de República Dominicana espera recibir en las “próximas semanas” o en los “próximos meses” una respuesta de las autoridades estadounidenses, a quienes propuso oficialmente la semana pasada eliminar el arancel del 10% que le impuso la Administración de Donald Trump. El canciller Roberto Álvarez dijo este lunes que durante su reunión del martes pasado con el representante comercial de Estados Unidos, Jamieson Greer, en la que participaron otros dos ministros dominicanos, este les dijo que República Dominicana es uno de los países que “mejor se comporta”. Sostuvieron una conversación de 33 minutos con el representante comercial Greer, quien recordó que el Gobierno de Donald Trump había aplicado al país caribeño la tarifa mínima (del 1 %) y que esta era la más global. Greer fue “muy cordial” durante la conversación que sostuvieron. República Dominicana solicitó a Estados Unidos eliminar el arancel del 10% que le impuso como parte de la política arancelaria de Trump. Álvarez dijo, en presencia del presidente dominicano, Luis Abinader, que esperan resolver este tema en las próximas semanas o en los próximos meses, a más tardar. A principios de abril, el Gobierno dominicano inició contactos diplomáticos con Estados Unidos para solicitar la eliminación del arancel del 10 % que afecta a productos nacionales, especialmente de zonas francas. Además, instó a respetar el Tratado de Libre Comercio firmado entre ambas naciones y Centroamérica. Abinader dijo que durante su conversación de varios minutos con Trump, cuando ambos participaron en los funerales del papa Francisco el sábado pasado, el estadounidense le dijo que el país estaba bien y lamentó la crisis de Haití. Trump le dijo que le encanta República Dominicana, que el país está bien y que ha jugado golf aquí. Abinader le dijo que esperaba su participación en la Cumbre de las Américas, que se celebrará a finales de año en el país.

title: Cepal recorta al 2 % el crecimiento en 2025 para Latinoamérica por la guerra comercial
content: Santiago de Chile, 29 abr (EFE).- La Comisión Económica para América Latina y el Caribe (Cepal) recortó este martes en cuatro décimas su previsión de crecimiento regional para este año y redujo su est ...
resumen:
La Comisión Económica para América Latina y el Caribe (Cepal) recortó su previsión de crecimiento regional para este año y redujo su estimación al 2 % debido a la guerra comercial. En diciembre pasado estimó un crecimiento regional del 2,4 %.

El mayor recorte previsto por Cepal es para el Caribe (del 2,6 % estimado en diciembre al 1,8 %) y para América Central y México (del 1,7 % al 1 %), mientras que la revisión de América del Sur es de solo una décima a la baja (del 2,6 % al 2,5 %).

De los 33 países de la región, solo Argentina, Perú y Ecuador registran revisiones al alza, mientras que los países con los mayores recortes en sus previsiones de crecimiento son Venezuela, México y Haití.

Argentina (5 %), República Dominicana (4,5 %), Costa Rica (3,6 %) y Paraguay (3,6 %) liderarán el crecimiento económico este año, según las nuevas cifras de Cepal.

En el medio de la tabla se encuentran Guatemala (3,3 %), Honduras (3,2 %), Nicaragua (3,1 %), Panamá (3,1 %), Perú (3,1 %), Uruguay (2,6 %), Colombia (2,5 %), El Salvador (2,5 %), Chile (2,2 %) y Brasil (2 %).

En la cola, pero aún con cifras positivas, están Bolivia (1,8 %), las islas del Caribe sin contar Guyana (1,8 %), Ecuador (1,5 %) y México (0,3 %), mientras que Cuba (-0,4 %), Venezuela (-1,5 %) y Haití (-2 %) son los únicos que decrecerán este año, según el organismo de Naciones Unidas.

Latinoamérica cerró 2023 y 2024 con un crecimiento del 2,3 %.

title: Trump celebra sus primeros 100 días en el cargo con un mitin en Michigan
content: Por WILL WEISSERT y JOEY CAPPELLETTIWARREN, Michigan, EE.UU. (AP) — El presidente Donald Trump hablará en un mitin en Michigan el martes para marcar los primeros 100 días de su ...
resumen:
El presidente Donald Trump está celebrando un mitin en Michigan el martes para marcar los primeros 100 días de su segundo mandato.

Trump está realizando una visita por la tarde a la Base de la Guardia Nacional Aérea de Selfridge para un anuncio junto a la gobernadora demócrata de Michigan, Gretchen Whitmer.

Está dando un discurso a miles de seguidores en el Macomb Community College, al norte de Detroit.

La Casa Blanca anunció que planeaba aliviar los aranceles automotrices.

Las estrictas políticas de inmigración de su administración republicana han hecho que las detenciones por cruces ilegales a lo largo de la frontera entre Estados Unidos y México caigan en picado, y los esfuerzos por reducir el gobierno liderados por el asesor multimillonario Elon Musk han sacudido a Washington hasta sus cimientos.

Trump ha defendido un amplio expansionismo, negándose a descartar la intervención militar en Groenlandia y Panamá, proponiendo que la Franja de Gaza sea convertida en un resort e incluso sugiriendo la anexión de Canadá.

Solo alrededor de cuatro de cada 10 estadounidenses aprueban cómo Trump está manejando la presidencia.

El 46% de los adultos en Estados Unidos aprueban las políticas de inmigración de Trump.

Solo el 33% de los estadounidenses tienen una opinión favorable de Musk.

La tasa de desempleo de Michigan ha aumentado durante tres meses consecutivos, incluyendo un salto del 1,3% desde marzo para alcanzar el 5,5%.

El fabricante de automóviles Stellantis detuvo la producción en plantas de Canadá y México después de que Trump anunciara un arancel del 25% sobre vehículos importados, despidiendo temporalmente a 900 empleados en Estados Unidos.

La secretaria de prensa de la Casa Blanca, Karoline Leavitt, declaró el martes por la mañana que Trump firmaría una orden ejecutiva relajando algunos de sus aranceles sobre autos y piezas de automóviles.

El secretario del Tesoro Scott Bessent aseveró que el objetivo seguía siendo permitir que los fabricantes de automóviles creen más empleos de manufactura doméstica.

Carolyn Martz, residente de Royal Oak, Michigan, apoya los aranceles del presidente.

El presidente también está visitando Selfridge y el campus del colegio comunitario en Warren.

Michigan será importante para los republicanos en 2026.

El discurso de Trump en el Macomb Community College será una de las pocas grandes multitudes en persona a las que se ha dirigido desde que fue juramentado el 20 de enero.

Whitmer se menciona frecuentemente como una futura candidata presidencial.

title: DOGE, tariffs and executive orders: A look at President Trump's first 100 days
content: President Donald Trump has reached his 100th day in office, a benchmark that is increasingly used to gauge early presidential success.The first 100 days of Trump’s second presidency have been defined ...
resumen: This week President Donald Trump has reached his 100th day in office. The first 100 days of Trump’s second presidency have been defined by record numbers of executive orders, sweeping tariffs that caused upheaval in global markets, a crackdown on border security and efforts to slash federal spending with the newly formed Department of Government Efficiency. Trump has signed 143 executive orders — over four times the amount he signed during his first 100 days in 2017. That’s more than the total number signed by each 21st century president combined during their first 100 days in office. One of the first executive orders Trump signed created DOGE — a department tasked with maximizing efficiency. Through DOGE, Trump directed federal agencies to initiate large-scale reductions in force. An analysis by the Hearst Television Data Team shows at least 49,000 employees were laid off. Trump has dismantled USAID, exited the World Health Organization and withdrawn from the UN Human Rights Council. Trump has carried out campaign promises to eliminate DEI practices in the federal workforce and prevent transgender individuals from serving in the military and participating in collegiate sports. He also pardoned Jan. 6 defendants, started dismantling the Department of Education, pushed back the Tik Tok ban and released JFK assassination files. About 45% of the executive orders closely mirror policies Project 2025 advocates for, a Hearst Television Data Team analysis found. Project 2025 was spearheaded by conservative think tank The Heritage Foundation. According to a Gallup poll, Trump had a slight edge with voters favoring him to handle the economy. A recent Gallup poll showed 59% of Americans feel the economic conditions in the country are “getting worse” and 36% said the economy was “getting better.” Trump has addressed the economy by rolling back regulations and protections across various industries. On day one, he declared a national energy emergency. The dip in approval follows Trump’s announcement of blanket tariffs with increased reciprocal tariffs on certain countries, especially China. The stock market plummeted and the administration has since announced a 90-day pause on the tariffs. The consumer price index eased from the high 3% in January to 2.4% inflation in March. Of the 143 executive orders that Trump has issued, about one third have faced lawsuits. The administration has faced 123 lawsuits challenging the legality and implementation of these orders, with nine actions currently fully blocked by the courts.

title: Local port commissioners warn of rising costs and supply chain disruptions as a result of trade war with China
content: Local ports warn of rising costs and supply chain issues due to the trade war with China, impacting Seattle and Tacoma's traffic.
resumen: The ports of Seattle and Tacoma are grappling with a significant slowdown in container traffic due to trade tensions between the United States and China. Port officials warn the situation could worsen, potentially leading to empty store shelves and economic strain on small and medium-sized businesses. Ryan Calkins, Port of Seattle Commissioner, described a decline in vessel activity at major terminals, attributing the slowdown to tariffs imposed during the Trump administration, which have strained trade relations with China, the region’s largest trading partner. China is the largest consumer of soybeans coming out of the Midwest, and Boeing sells a lot of airplanes to China. Dick Marzano, Port of Tacoma Commissioner, highlighted the toll on agricultural exports, particularly apples and cherries. Both ports are working to mitigate the impact by diversifying trade partnerships. Commissioners from Seattle and Tacoma are currently in Asia, exploring opportunities in Vietnam and Korea, where tariffs are less restrictive. The slowdown has raised concerns about potential shortages of goods. Calkins warned that for certain commodities, it’s probably weeks, not months, before we see shortages. Families may face challenges due to the trade war. Affordable clothing brands could become less affordable, and big-ticket items will also become more expensive. The Trump administration has said talks are ongoing with China and that a deal is being worked on, but China has said no talks are happening. Calkins suggested internal disagreements within the Trump administration may be delaying resolution.

title: Donald Trump produced one ugly economic baby in his first 100 days | Opinion
content: Tariffs will be what we remember from the first 100 days of the second Trump administration, a mistake of historic proportions.
resumen: Economist Lawrence Summers warns of a potential financial crisis due to Donald Trump's tariffs. Indicators such as falling bond prices, declining foreign investment and warnings from major retailers suggest the negative impact of the tariffs is already being felt. Consumer confidence has plummeted, and experts predict job losses in the manufacturing sector due to the tariffs. Summers served as Bill Clinton’s treasury secretary, was director of the National Economic Council during the Obama era and formerly served as president of Harvard. Summers warned that the $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan could trigger massive inflation. Now that Trump has acted and imposed tariffs on many of our global trading partners, Summers warns of something ominous. He wrote in a series of X posts on April 9, “We may be headed for serious financial crisis wholly induced by U.S. government tariff policy.” For 40 years, Trump has relished the idea of imposing across-the-board tariffs, Summers told the online magazine Puck in an interview published on April 23. At the start of 2025, foreign investors held a record 18% ownership share of U.S. equities, Goldman Sachs reported. “We estimate (they) have sold roughly $60 billion of U.S. stocks since the start of March.” Three top U.S. retailers, Walmart, Target and Home Depot, met with President Trump and warned of shortages and higher prices in the offing. Goldman Sachs’s chief economist, Jan Hatzius, projected that Trump’s tariffs would destroy five American manufacturing jobs for every one it creates. The volume of goods arriving at the Port of Los Angeles has dropped sharply, and daily container bookings on the U.S.-China trade route have tumbled by a quarter relative to this time last year, The Times of London reports. Tariffs and other Trump insults have provoked a sharp decline in international tourism to the United States, Travel Tomorrow reports. “In March alone, overseas visits to the U.S. dropped by 11.6% compared to the previous year,” the website reported. American consumer confidence is in full collapse, falling 40% since Trump’s election to a 45-year low, according to the University of Michigan consumer sentiment survey. Billionaire hedge fund manager Ken Griffin told The Wall Street Journal that Trump’s tariffs are a “huge policy mistake” that means the governments must tell middle class consumers “it’s going to cost you 20%, 30%, 40% more for your groceries, for your toaster, for a new vacuum cleaner, for a new car.” Conservatives such as the Hoover Institution’s Niall Ferguson are railing against the policy. The Wall Street Journal’s Gerard Baker shares that “We may be witnessing now the greatest exercise in brand destruction in history.” Multiple polls show that Trump’s support is falling fast.

title: The Spring of Tariff Regret
content: The IMF has reviewed the global growth downward, highlighting the impacts of Trump’s tariff war and warning about financial and economic risks.
resumen: The IMF downgraded its global growth forecast by half a percentage point to 2.8% for this year and lowered its 2026 forecast to 3%. This represents a slowdown from the 3.3% growth rate in 2024. The forecast factored in only the tariff announcements from the U.S. and retaliatory measures from other countries between February 1 and April 4. The Fund cut its U.S. growth forecast for 2025 to 1.8% and to 1.7% in 2026. The IMF also downgraded growth projections for all other G7 countries, as well as for other major economies, including China, India, Brazil, and South Africa. China is expected to slow down, with the IMF forecasting 4% growth for both this year and next, compared to 5% in 2024. Brazil’s real GDP growth forecast was lowered to 2% for both 2025 and 2026. Among G20 countries, only Turkey, Argentina, and Russia showed improved growth projections. The IMF’s Global Financial Stability Report concluded that risks to markets have "increased significantly" since the White House’s tariff moves, with a selloff in U.S. equities and government debt contributing to a "tightening of financial conditions.” The announcement of the “reciprocal tariffs” on April 2 had an immediate negative impact on stock markets, and starting on April 7, similar effects were seen in U.S. government bond markets. Yields on 10-year Treasury bonds rose while the dollar depreciated. Global portfolios visibly began shedding U.S. assets. Up until the announcement of the massive “reciprocal tariffs” on April 2, it was believed that Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent’s view prevailed. The shock came on April 2, with the rise of Howard Lutnick (Secretary of Commerce), Peter Navarro (Senior Counselor for Trade and Manufacturing), and Jamieson Greer (U.S. Trade Representative). The 90-day postponement of the “reciprocal tariffs”—even with the China-specific increases—came during Scott Bessent’s presence at the White House. Trump threatened to fire Federal Reserve Governor Jeremy Powell. The U.S. intensified the tariff war with China without even minimal preparation for realities such as China currently processing over 90% of critical minerals and magnets necessary for digital products. Trump and Bessent speak of negotiations between the two countries, while the Chinese insist that talks can only begin once the U.S. rolls back specific new measures targeting China. On Tuesday, April 22, Secretary Scott Bessent said at a conference organized by JPMorgan that he hoped the two countries would eventually reach an agreement. On Friday 25 of April, there were reports that China’s Ministry of Commerce was reviewing sectors affected by Beijing’s 125% tariffs on U.S. products, according to Michael Hart, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in China. Beijing denied that any negotiations to ease trade tensions between the world’s two largest economies had started. One of Trump’s first executive orders was a review of these relationships, with a report due in August. Secretary Scott Bessent did not call for an exit but emphasized tying U.S. contributions to a shift in institutional focus. He criticized the IMF and World Bank for “mission drift,” demanding they steer away from “extensive and unfocused agendas” like climate change and gender issues. According to Tobias Adrian, director of the IMF’s Monetary and Capital Markets Department, equity and bond prices could “certainly” fall further if negotiations fail. Otaviano Canuto, based in Washington, D.C, is a former vice president and a former executive director at the World Bank, a former executive director at the International Monetary Fund, and a former vice president at the Inter-American Development Bank. He is also a former deputy minister for international affairs at Brazil’s Ministry of Finance and a former professor of economics at the University of São Paulo and the University of Campinas, Brazil. Currently, he is a senior fellow at the Policy Center for the New South, a professorial lecturer of international affairs at the Elliott School of International Affairs - George Washington University, a nonresident senior fellow at Brookings Institution, a professor affiliate at UM6P, and principal at Center for Macroeconomics and Development.

title: Trump’s tariffs: Eastern Europe likely to weather the storm
content: Despite global trade tensions and manufacturing slowdown in Germany, Central and Eastern European economies demonstrate remarkable resilience with growth projections significantly outpacing the euro ...
resumen:
Trump’s tariffs: Eastern Europe likely to weather the storm.

April 29, 2025.

Central and Eastern European economies demonstrate remarkable resilience with growth projections significantly outpacing the euro area.

Eastern Europe appears positioned to withstand the economic headwinds, according to the latest spring forecast from the Vienna Institute for International Economic Studies (wiiw).

The report, covering 23 countries across Central, East and Southeast Europe, shows that most economies in the region—including EU member states—will maintain robust growth throughout 2025, even as the euro area struggles.

The direct trade flows between those countries and the US are anyway low, and the collateral damage caused by their close ties with the heavily export-dependent German industry is also likely to remain manageable.

Those countries with larger domestic markets—most notably Poland—will be better able to absorb the negative impact and are likely once again to prove resilient.

For 2025, analysts at wiiw forecast average growth of 2.5 per cent for the EU members in the region, which represents a modest downward revision of 0.3 percentage points compared to their winter forecast. Looking ahead to 2026, growth should tick up slightly to 2.8 per cent.

The negative effects of Trump’s tariffs should be largely offset next year by Germany’s fiscal policy about-turn, with its 500 billion euros package for defence, infrastructure and climate.

Eastern European EU members will likely grow approximately three times faster than the euro area in 2025 (where growth is expected to be just 0.7 per cent) and twice as fast in 2026 (compared to the euro area’s projected 1.4 per cent).

Despite the manufacturing slump in Germany—which is expected to worsen due to Trump’s tariffs—industrial challenges in Czechia, Slovakia, Hungary, and Romania won’t derail overall growth.

Poland remains the standout performer among eastern EU members, with projected GDP growth of 3.5 per cent for both 2025 and 2026, followed by Croatia at 2.8 per cent.

The Western Balkans six are expected to expand by an average of three per cent in 2025 and 3.6 per cent in 2026, while Turkey’s economy is forecast to grow by 3.5 per cent in 2025 and four per cent in 2026.

Ukraine: Growth dependent on external support.

While wiiw forecasts three per cent growth in 2025 and four per cent in 2026, these projections depend heavily on continued external military and financial assistance—support that has been jeopardised under President Trump.

Trump’s attempts to force Ukraine into de facto capitulation and to turn the country into an economic colony of the US are, however, the biggest threat to Ukraine’s economic development.

The decisive factor will therefore be whether the EU succeeds in stepping up its military and financial aid to Ukraine and in replacing the US as the country’s most important supporter.

Ukraine faces multiple challenges beyond geopolitics, including systematic infrastructure destruction from Russian air strikes, acute labour shortages due to military mobilisation and the emigration of seven million people.

Rising food and public service prices, combined with wage growth driven by labour scarcity, have pushed inflation higher, prompting the central bank to raise interest rates to 15.5 per cent.

Russia: Prospects improve under Trump.

Although growth is expected to halve in 2025 following two years of economic overheating, wiiw has revised its 2025 forecast upward by 0.2 percentage points to two per cent. For 2026, it projects growth of 2.5 per cent—a significant upward revision of 0.9 percentage points from their winter forecast.

Should there actually be a ceasefire or peace agreement in Ukraine, Russia’s economic ostracisation by the US will probably end. It is even feasible that this will happen without an agreement. That would allow US capital and American technology to flow back into the country. US allies like Japan, South Korea and Taiwan could also follow suit.

The existing US sanctions are already being implemented only half-heartedly.

The warming relations with the US have boosted Russian financial markets and strengthened the ruble. Foreign companies including Renault, Hyundai, and Samsung are contemplating returning to Russia, while South Korean electronics giant LG has already restarted production at its Moscow plant.

The partial resumption of economic relations with the West would probably make up for the loss of soldiers’ high salaries and compensation for their families, which have been a major source of Russian growth since the invasion of Ukraine, if the war were to end.

Even the recent sharp decline in crude oil prices—Russia’s primary export—is unlikely to significantly impact the country’s positive outlook.

The forecast faces significant downside risks stemming from uncertainty among consumers and businesses, fueled by Trump’s erratic trade policies and potential escalation of the conflict with China.

We are now witnessing a full-scale trade war between the US and China, which will have an adverse impact on the entire global economy. High volatility on the financial markets could escalate into a financial crisis, which may then spill over into the real economy.

It is not yet really possible to predict how the general uncertainty will affect consumption or investment, even though the region has repeatedly shown itself to be very resilient to external shocks.

US policy toward Ukraine creates additional uncertainty with potential economic repercussions if peace efforts fail.

At the moment, it doesn’t look as if Trump will be able to convince Russian President Putin to end the war of aggression against Ukraine. If Trump then turns away in frustration and leaves Ukraine to its fate, that could once again shake the economy of Central Eastern Europe.

The Vienna Institute for International Economic Studies (wiiw) forecasts.

title: Tabaqueros dominicanos observan con cautela aranceles de Trump
content: Tabaqueros dominicanos observan con cautela el impacto de los aranceles de Trump en su producto estrella: el cigarro premium.
resumen:
Tras la imposición de nuevos aranceles por parte de la administración del presidente de los Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, la industria tabacalera de República Dominicana observa con cautela el impacto que estas medidas podrían tener en su producto estrella de exportación: el cigarro premium.

En un reportaje especial de la periodista Katherine Hernández, se recogen las voces de actores clave del sector que piden mantener la serenidad y confiar en la activación de mecanismos diplomáticos.

Iván Hernández, director del Instituto del Tabaco de la República Dominicana, expresó: “Que hay que verlo, yo digo que con la cabeza fría y verlo en contexto global. A nosotros nos pongan un 10, pero tal vez a nuestro mayor competidor le pongan un 36, entonces si ahora estamos en igualdad de condiciones, inmediatamente, aun teniendo el 10, pasamos a tener una situación competitiva ventajosa”.

Ciro Cascella, presidente de empresa tabacalera, dijo: “Pero el tema arancelario hay que esperar a ver en qué queda y nada, yo creo que, si se lo ponen a todo el mundo, hay que marchar sobre las imposiciones”.

Recientemente una comisión del Gobierno dominicano viajó a Washington para sostener conversaciones formales con autoridades estadounidenses sobre los aranceles. El objetivo es buscar vías que garanticen la estabilidad del comercio bilateral.

Actualmente, el 75 % del tabaco dominicano exportado tiene como destino el mercado norteamericano.

La industria del tabaco en la República Dominicana genera más de 110,000 empleos directos y miles indirectos en el 2025. Esto según informó el director del Instituto del Tabaco (Intabaco), Iván Hernández Guzmán.

Hernández Guzmán indicó que las industrias que generan mayor cantidad de empleos del sector son La Aurora, La Tabacalera, Swisher Dominicana, Imperial Tobacco, Occidental Cigars, La Flor Dominicana, entre otras. Siendo Santiago la provincia donde se encuentran más naves de elaboración del producto.

title: Por guerra comercial de Trump, Cepal rebaja estimación de crecimiento de Colombia y otros latinoamericanos
content: La organización advierte que América Latina enfrenta un entorno internacional incierto y volátil, marcado por tensiones geoeconómicas.
resumen:
La Comisión Económica para América Latina y el Caribe (Cepal) bajó su pronóstico para el Producto Interno Bruto (PIB) de Colombia y América Latina.

En Colombia, la estimación se redujo a 2,5 % ((-0,1 %) de la medición anterior).

Argentina tiene una proyección de 5 %, Paraguay con el 3,6 %, Perú con el 3,1 % y Uruguay a 2,6 %.

El balance preliminar hecho a finales de 2024 indicó que el PIB de América Latina sería de 2,2 %, sin embargo, la nueva revisión lo reduce a 2 %.

En cuanto a América del Sur, el panorama mejoró, pasando de 2,3 % a 2,5 %.

Venezuela, cuyo crecimiento era de 6,2 % para 2024 y ahora se cree que la economía caiga en -1,5 %.

Para América Central, se proyecta un crecimiento del 2,7 % en 2025, una leve disminución respecto al 2,8 % estimado para 2024.

Costa Rica y Guatemala mantienen tasas elevadas (3,6 % y 3,3 % respectivamente), mientras que Haití enfrenta una caída proyectada del 2 %.

México muestra un crecimiento modesto, de 1,5 % en 2024, y una ligera mejora a 1,7 % en 2025.

El promedio combinado de América Central y México para 2025 es apenas del 1 %, lo que representa una fuerte revisión a la baja de 0,7 puntos porcentuales.

En el Caribe, República Dominicana y Panamá mantienen proyecciones sólidas, con crecimientos del 4,5 % y 3 % respectivamente en 2025.

La organización advierte que América Latina enfrenta un entorno internacional incierto y volátil, marcado por tensiones geoeconómicas, como el aumento de aranceles por parte de Estados Unidos.

La Cepal ajustó sus proyecciones para 2025, previendo una desaceleración tanto de la demanda externa como interna.

title: Banco Santander y su apoyo a la internacionalización de las empresas
content: La nueva unidad Santander Multinationals proporciona el apoyo y la seguridad necesarios para operar y crecer en los mercados internacionales ...
resumen:
Banco Santander ha creado Santander Multinationals, una nueva división para ayudar a las empresas a expandirse internacionalmente.
La nueva unidad proporciona apoyo y seguridad para operar y crecer en los mercados internacionales.
Los beneficios de la internacionalización incluyen el incremento del tamaño empresarial, la generación de nuevas oportunidades de negocio, mayor resiliencia frente a las crisis, reducción de riesgos y un aumento de la rentabilidad, que se estima en torno al 35%.
Las exportaciones suponen el 42% del PIB español.
Un 77,6% de empresas exportadoras lo hace de manera regular.
Raúl Mínguez, director del Servicio de Estudios de Cámara de España, señala que la internacionalización se ha convertido en una parte habitual de la estrategia de negocio para muchas empresas españolas.
Santander Multinationals opera en 14 mercados: Alemania, Argentina, Brasil, Chile, Colombia, España, Estados Unidos, México, Perú, Polonia, Portugal, Reino Unido, Uruguay, y también China, a través de un acuerdo con Bank of Shanghai.
La división presta servicio a más de 18.000 empresas clientes de banca comercial.
Entre los servicios que ofrece, destacan un proceso de on-boarding especializado, acceso a la herramienta de gestión de tesorería Cash Nexus, soluciones de divisa y cobertura de riesgos.
Las empresas clientes también pueden trabajar con Getnet, compañía de Santander líder en soluciones de pago para comercios físicos y digitales.
Yann Louvrier, responsable global de Multinacionales en Banco Santander, se muestra convencido de que la próxima oleada de internacionalización no se limitará a grandes corporaciones.
El comercio global alcanzó un récord de 33 billones de dólares en 2024, con un crecimiento del 3,7%.
Según previsiones de DHL, el volumen de comercio mundial aumentará a una media anual del 3,1% entre 2024 y 2029.
Otras estimaciones de la OCDE advierten de que la combinación de aranceles, presiones inflacionistas y tensiones geopolíticas podría ralentizar el crecimiento global al 3,1% en 2025 y al 3,0% en 2026.

title: Is Your 401(k) Affected by Trump’s Tariffs? Here’s What to Know and What You Should Do
content: Markets extended a global selloff on April 4 as countries around the world reeled from President Donald Trump's tariffs. Reporter The U.S. and global stock markets have been hit hard since ...
resumen:
The U.S. and global stock markets have been hit hard since President Donald Trump announced his latest tariffs on April 2. The so-called “Liberation Day” saw the introduction of blanket 10% tariffs on all imported goods, and additional import taxes placed on 60 other countries. In the worst week for U.S. stocks since the markets crashed in 2020 during the COVID-19 pandemic, Dow Jones closed on Friday 2,000 points down, the S&P Index plunged 6%, and Nasdaq dipped almost 6%.

There has also been a surge in concerns being voiced by people worried about the impact on their 401(k), as many have noticed a dip in their investments. A 401(k) is an employer-sponsored retirement plan where a person has the option to make contributions that are deducted from their paycheck. The value of 401(k) accounts is closely tied to fluctuations in the stock markets. With such extreme dips in the stock market, some Americans are seeing their retirement savings take an intense hit.

During an appearance on NBC's Meet the Press on Sunday, April 6, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent was asked about the market turmoil and the concerns regarding retirement savings. Host Kristen Welker said: “More than 160 million Americans are invested in the market. Many of them have spent their lives saving for their retirement. What is your message to Americans who want to retire right now and who've just seen their lifetime savings drop significantly?” Responding to the question, Bessent remarked that he thinks it's a “false narrative,” and suggested that people maintain a “long-term view.” Bessent said that most Americans in a 401(k) have what's called a '60/40 account,' and that 60/40 accounts are down 5 or 6% on the year.

On April 3, when aboard Air Force One, Trump was asked by a reporter about the rising concerns among Americans and whether he has checked his own 401(k) since his tariff announcements stunned the stock market. Trump said: “I haven’t checked my 401(k).” The President also doubled down on his belief that though the markets look bad now, his tariffs will ultimately be a good thing for the economy. The President once again shared his optimism about the economy in an update he posted on his social media platform, Truth Social, on Saturday, April 5.

Teresa Fort, associate professor of business administration at Dartmouth, says: “the entire world economic order has been shifted, and people are going to need to rethink what [their] optimal allocations should be.”

Brad Clark, founder and CEO of Solomon Financial, says that this is not the time to panic and take your money out of savings. For people two or three years from retirement, Clark says their portfolios should already be less risky, and they should not have full market exposure to their investments. For those who are still 10 or more years away from retirement, Clark’s advice is to “continue to invest like you’ve always invested.” In a column for the Washington Post, personal finance columnist and author Michelle Singletary echoed this sentiment.

Laurence Kotlikoff, professor of economics at Boston University, takes a more cautious approach for people of all ages. He recommends not investing in anything risky now, instead starting back from a safe investment position and eventually building your investment portfolio back into something more risky. He also recommends people consider doing what he and his wife did soon after Trump’s Inauguration Day. In preparation of potential market fluctuations, they built a TIPS ladder, which is a portfolio of Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities. Fort echoes Kotlikoff’s caution.

title: 100 days: The US stock market's rollercoaster ride since Trump took office
content: Trump makes a momentous political comeback, breaking through the "blue wall" to win 312 electoral votes. Trump becomes only the second US president in history to be elected to non-consecutive terms, ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump’s first 100 days coincided with the stock market’s third-worst start to any presidency in US history, only behind Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford.

The S&P 500 posted back-to-back gains of more than 20% the past two years.

100 days into Trump’s presidency, Wall Street has been shaken by historic levels of uncertainty and volatility.

The S&P 500 slumped as Trump rolled out his plan for trade policy, hitting its lowest level of the year on April 8.

The S&P 500 is still below where it was before Trump unveiled his “reciprocal” tariffs.

Trump becomes only the second US president in history to be elected to non-consecutive terms, following Grover Cleveland (the 22nd and 24th US president).

Bitcoin, the world's largest cryptocurrency, surpasses $100,000 for the first time ever.

After the S&P 500 gained 23% across 2024, and 24% across 2023.

Trump said in an Oval Office signing ceremony that his administration would levy a 25% tariff on Mexico and Canada starting February 1.

Trump signs the first executive order laying out a plan to impose tariffs: 10% on China and 25% on Mexico and Canada.

Stocks slide after Trump announces his plan for tariffs.

The S&P 500 closes at an all-time record high.

During Trump's first 100 days, the index never gets higher than this point.

Bitcoin tumbles as low as $78,250, falling below the $80,000 threshold for the first time since November.

Trump's 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico go into effect, while the tariff on China rises to 20%.

The S&P 500 slides 1.2%, erasing all gains since Trump was re-elected.

The S&P 500 drops 2.7% and the Dow drops 2.08% in one day.

The Nasdaq records its biggest single-day decline since 2022.

The S&P 500 closes in correction territory (down 10% or more from a record high) for the first time since 2023.

The Dow posts its worst week since 2023.

The first quarter of the year ends. The S&P 500 posts its worst quarterly performance since 2022.

Trump unveils his "Liberation Day" tariffs after the closing bell.

Trump announces his plan for "reciprocal" tariffs during a ceremony at the White House.

Dow futures drop more than 1,100 points, or 2.7%.

The Dow plunges by 2,231 points, or 5.5%. The S&P 500 drops 5.97%. The Nasdaq slides 5.82%.

The Nasdaq closes in a bear market — down more than 20% — for the first time since 2022.

The S&P 500 drops to its lowest level this year.

The S&P 500 drops to its lowest level this year.

Trump unveils a 90-day pause on most reciprocal tariffs.

The biggest single-day gain for the S&P 500 since 2008 and also the third-biggest one-day surge in modern history.

The market is still well below the level it was at before Trump announced his reciprocal tariffs on April 2.

The Dow, after rising nearly 3,000 points the day before, falls 1,015 points.

Apple's stock (AAPL) has tumbled this year.

Consumer sentiment plunged 11% this month to a preliminary reading of 50.8, according to the University of Michigan's latest survey.

It is the second-lowest reading on record going back to 1952.

The exemptions for electronics are only a temporary reprieve. Those products will face separate levies, according to Lutnick.

Apple stock gains a modest 2.2% that day.

The US dollar index, which measures the dollar's strength against six major foreign currencies, tumbles to its lowest level in three years.
