title: Trump cumple 100 días de gobierno con un coctel de autoritarismo y desregulación
content: En su retorno a la Casa Blanca, Trump desplegó una ofensiva sin precedentes contra el Estado federal, los organismos multilaterales y los derechos migratorios.
resumen:
En los primeros 100 días de su segundo mandato, el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, implementó un ritmo de autoritarismo y polarización constante. Su agenda combina el desmantelamiento del aparato estatal, una política exterior agresiva y una cruzada migratoria sin precedentes. Trump recurrió reiteradamente al decreto presidencial para moldear el funcionamiento del gobierno federal, bajo la influencia de su aliado, el empresario Elon Musk. Impuso aranceles unilaterales que provocaron una guerra comercial global, ejecutó detenciones y deportaciones masivas y sostuvo su política de "máxima presión" en el escenario internacional.

Trump firmó más de 170 órdenes ejecutivas para imponer aranceles, perseguir la migración irregular y desmantelar organismos federales, eludiendo al Congreso. El DOGE, encabezado por Musk, lideró una "purga burocrática" que incluyó el desguace de la Agencia de Estados Unidos para el Desarrollo Internacional (USAID) y miles de despidos en el sector federal. Musk congeló fondos millonarios, recopiló información de empleados y exigió que justificaran la continuidad de sus cargos. Trump eliminó las políticas de Diversidad, Equidad e Inclusión (DEI) en agencias federales, dirigió ataques ideológicos contra universidades y retiró financiamiento público. El recorte masivo en el Departamento de Salud y Servicios Humanos (HHS) dejó sin empleo a más de 10 mil profesionales sanitarios.

Trump reseteó la política exterior estadounidense a la doctrina de "la ley del más fuerte". Retomó el desprecio por los organismos multilaterales y fortaleció las relaciones bilaterales. Intentó forzar un acuerdo exprés en Ucrania, frenó la ayuda militar a Kiev y empujó a negociaciones con concesiones a Rusia. Renovó su acercamiento a Moscú y tuvo un trato hostil al presidente ucraniano Volodimir Zelenski.

El "acuerdo épico de tregua" en la Franja de Gaza colapsó en marzo, causando más de 2.100 muertes. Trump propuso que Estados Unidos tomara el control del enclave expulsando a sus habitantes. Reactivó su interés por territorios como Groenlandia, presionó a China por su presencia en el canal de Panamá y sugirió que Canadá podría convertirse en el "Estado 51". Consolidó una diplomacia basada en la lealtad personal a su figura, como es el caso de sus aliados latinoamericanos, como Nayib Bukele y Javier Milei.

El 2 de abril, Trump anunció aranceles masivos, pero el caos bursátil lo forzó a dar marcha atrás, manteniendo solo los aranceles sobre acero, aluminio y productos chinos. La pausa estaría vigente "hasta que tengamos las cifras que quiero tener". El secretario del Tesoro, Scott Bessent, confesó que la guerra comercial, en los términos actuales, es "insostenible".

La promesa de ejecutar la mayor campaña de deportaciones ha sido una piedra angular de la narrativa migratoria de Trump. En estos 100 días firmó más de 170 decretos en la materia, involucrando incluso al Pentágono y al Departamento de Justicia en operativos migratorios. El gobierno celebró el aumento de arrestos diarios, que pasaron de 310 a más de 650, pero evitó publicar datos completos sobre deportaciones. Se reportaron múltiples detenciones irregulares, incluso de ciudadanos estadounidenses y migrantes con estatus legal. Trump suspendió el parole humanitario para Cuba, Haití, Nicaragua y Venezuela, dejando a más de medio millón de personas en un limbo legal. Comenzó a usar la base naval de Guantánamo para retener migrantes antes de deportarlos a terceros países. En marzo Trump invocó la Ley de Enemigos Extranjeros para encarcelar a más de 200 migrantes en El Salvador. Human Rights Watch calificó esta medida como una "desaparición forzada". La Corte Suprema ordenó una pausa, pero el Ejecutivo desoyó la decisión.

Según encuestas, Trump cuenta con el porcentaje de aprobación más bajo en sus primeros 100 días en el gobierno que cualquier presidente en las últimas siete décadas. Un sondeo de CNN realizado por la consultora SSRS indica un índice de aprobación del 41 por ciento.

title: Trade war hits Amazon Prime Day harder than ever as sellers back out
content: Some third-party merchants who previously sold China-made goods during Amazon's premier July shopping event are sitting it out this year.
resumen: Amazon's Prime Day is losing its appeal among sellers. Some third-party merchants are sitting out or reducing discounts due to the U.S.-China trade war and tariffs on Chinese goods. Steve Green, who sells $230 bicycles and $60 skateboards from China, is skipping Prime Day for the first time since 2020. The China tariffs, which stand at 145%, will more than double his costs of goods on newly imported merchandise. Kim Vaccarella, chief executive of Bogg Bag, decided to skip Prime Day to retain unsold U.S. inventory. She's halted production of China-made Bogg Bags, which sell for $70 to $200 on Amazon, while she works to move manufacturing to Cambodia and Vietnam. Amazon has around 200 million Prime subscribers worldwide. Arun Sundaram, an analyst at CFRA Research, said that third-party sellers are going to be hurt the most in this environment. An Amazon spokesperson said it is having a "strong response from selling partners to Prime Day 2025." The deadline for electing to participate in Prime Day is May 23. Rick Sliter, CEO of MedCline, which sells $250 therapeutic pillows made in China and Vietnam, said he was likely to hold off on offering discounts during Prime Day. The average Amazon seller reaps about 15% to 20% of a sale as a profit after cost of goods sold and Amazon's fees. Amazon takes a 15% commission on each unit sold, not including the fees required to advertise and host discounts on Prime Day. Sellers pay Amazon $1,000 to have a discount highlighted as a “Best Deal” or $500 to have an item highlighted as a “Lightning Deal." Adam Wilkens, who advises about 30 Amazon merchants, said that some of his clients "can't even think about Prime Day yet because they don't have their tariff pricing adjustments finalized." U.S. shoppers spent $14.2 billion during Prime Day last year. Amazon has not announced the exact date for Prime Day, but said it would spread across four days in July. Green said that he paid between $200 to $500 in Amazon fees and gave $3,000 to $5,000 in discounts during last year's Prime Day. Chief Executive Andy Jassy said during a CNBC interview on April 10 that it is doing “strategic forward inventory buys” and renegotiating terms to keep prices low for shoppers amid the China tariffs. Third-party sellers accounted for nearly 62% of units sold in the fourth quarter of 2024. Michael Slate is not offering discounts. Jon Elder, a consultant who counts 100 Amazon sellers as clients, said that nearly all his clients are pulling back in Prime Day deals.

The goal of the polls is to tap into public sentiment on critical matters ranging from which leader ran the best campaign to whether Donald Trump's tariff and annexation threats swayed their vote. The Canadian electoral system uses a "first-past-the-post" voting model. In 2015, the then-PM Justin Trudeau had vowed to abolish the first-past-the-post voting system. Canada witnessed record advance voting numbers to set the stage for April 28 election day with 7.3 million Canadians casting their ballots over the four days of advance polling during the Easter long weekend. Canadian readers largely supported the Conservatives, while also marking cost of living and Trump's threats as their top two priorities with respect to life in Canada. The Conservative Party of Canada dominated each, suggesting a slightly different narrative than polls across the country which show the Liberals with a lead. As part of their Canada-wide campaign in the lead up to April 28, leaders remained razor-sharped in addressing trade tensions with Trump, tax cuts and domestic industrial growth.

title: Why Trump’s Economic Disruption Will Be Hard to Reverse
content: The president’s turnover of the economic order has unleashed changes that could prove lasting, because other countries will adjust.
resumen: President Trump has made clear his intent to smash the reigning global economic order and has made remarkable progress in accomplishing that goal in 100 days. Mr. Trump has provoked a trade war, scrapped treaties and suggested that Washington might not defend Europe. He is also dismantling the governmental infrastructure that has provided the know-how and experience. Midterm elections in two years could erode the Republican majority in Congress, and Mr. Trump’s reign is constitutionally mandated to end in four years. Historians and political scientists agree that on some crucial counts, the changes wrought by Mr. Trump may be hard to reverse. The erosion of trust in the United States took generations to build. Ian Goldin, professor of globalization and development at the University of Oxford, said that the conditions that propelled the “Make America Great Again” movement — widening inequality and economic insecurity — remain. Allies are working to strike trade partnerships and build security alliances that exclude the United States. The European Union and South American countries recently created one of the world’s largest trade zones. Mark Carney, the Canadian prime minister, recently proposed building new transportation networks to ease access to global markets outside the United States. Canada is also negotiating to join Europe’s military buildup to reduce its reliance on the United States, while Britain and the European Union are working to finalize a defense pact. Supply chains will be rearranged, new partnerships will be struck, and foreign students, researchers and tech talent will find other places to migrate. Mr. Trump is emboldening autocratic leaders around the world, which further chips away at the rules-based system. Mr. Trump’s disdain for international institutions only strengthens the influence of China. Orville Schell, director of the Center on U.S.-China Relations at the Asia Society in New York, said the administration is creating “immense moments of opportunity for Xi Jinping and China.” China’s top leader, Mr. Xi, is seeking to exploit Mr. Trump’s protectionist turn and chaotic policy reversals to better position Beijing as the defender of free trade and the new leader of the global trading system. Jonathan Czin, a fellow at the Brookings Institution’s China Center and a former senior China analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency, said China looks “steady and stable and a picture of equanimity compared to the United States.” Mr. Trump has gutted the U.S. Agency for International Development. The reorganization plan for the State Department has proposed eliminating nearly all diplomatic missions across the continent. China has already invested deeply in Africa as part of its Belt and Road Initiative, and its push to control more of the continent’s critical minerals. Mr. Czin said, “It creates a vacuum that allows China to consolidate that position and control over those mining rights.” Mr. Trump’s hostility to allies could also undercut government efforts in recent years to keep advanced technology out of China’s hands. Antony Hopkins, a history professor at Cambridge University, added that Mr. Trump was forgetting the important role China played as an international investor and buyer of U.S. debt. If China’s access to America’s large consumer market is severely curtailed, “you are courting the possibility of damaging China’s ability to invest in U.S. Treasury bonds, and if you do that, you’re shooting yourself in the foot.” As Mr. Trump threatened, and then paused until early July, potentially ruinous tariffs on the export-oriented economies of countries like Vietnam, Bangladesh and Indonesia, China gained an opportunity to strengthen ties. The evisceration of the federal government’s research and data collection capabilities risks undermining America’s scientific excellence and competitive edge. According to the National Center for Science and Engineering Statistics, the federal government finances roughly 40 percent of the long-term basic research that undergirds the country’s technological and scientific breakthroughs. The administration is cutting billions of dollars in grants to universities, scientists and researchers, undermining work on topics like environmental hazards, disease control, climate and clean energy programs, computer processing, agriculture, defense and artificial intelligence. It has slashed funding for the cybersecurity work that protects the power grid, pipelines and telecommunications. Thousands of veteran and up-and-coming experts have been fired. Institutions are worried about a brain drain as American and foreign researchers turn elsewhere for grants, jobs and academic freedom. Mr. Schell at the Asia Society said, “This is a revolution dedicated to destroying not only policies but institutions.” David Ekbladh, a history professor at Tufts University, said that in 1971 President Richard M. Nixon terminated the system of fixed exchange rates and severed the value of the U.S. dollar from gold.

title: Primer ministro de Belice informa a Marco Rubio sobre situación fronteriza con Guatemala
content: Ciudad de Panamá, 28 abr (EFE).- El primer ministro de Belice, John Briceño, dialogó por teléfono con el secretario de Estado de Estados Unidos, Marco Rubio, sobre los aranceles comerciales, la situac ...
resumen:
El primer ministro de Belice, John Briceño, dialogó por teléfono con el secretario de Estado de Estados Unidos, Marco Rubio, sobre los aranceles comerciales, la situación en Haití y la disputa fronteriza que mantiene con Guatemala.

El ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores beliceño informó que «ambos hablaron sobre intereses bilaterales, como la inversión, la MCC (las siglas en inglés de la agencia estadounidense de ayuda al exterior, Corporación Reto del Milenio), y el régimen de aranceles comerciales».

En septiembre pasado, la directora ejecutiva de MCC, Alice Albright, y Briceño firmaron el llamado Pacto de Belice por valor de 125 millones de dólares «diseñado para generar un crecimiento económico sostenible e inclusivo para el pueblo de Belice», en concreto dirigido a «mejorar la educación y reducir los costos energéticos», según MCC.

El primer ministro de Belice «actualizó al secretario de Estado sobre el caso Belice-Guatemala» ante la Corte Internacional de Justicia (CIJ), ya que ambos países centroamericanos mantienen una vieja disputa territorial sobre sus fronteras por el reclamo de Guatemala sobre unos 11.000 kilómetros cuadrados, casi la mitad del territorio beliceño.

La disputa llegó a la CIJ después de que Guatemala avalara en una consulta popular en 2018 para llevar el caso a La Haya (Países Bajos) en 2019 y se espera esa resolución este año.

Briceño y Rubio también «abordaron la situación en Haití, donde se necesita urgentemente un mayor apoyo internacional para evitar una crisis aún mayor».

title: Secretario del Tesoro de EE.UU. dijo que depende de China dar el primer paso para reducir medidas arancelarias
content: Bessent, secretario del Tesoro, afirmó en una entrevista para CNBC que el hecho de que China haya eximido a algunos productos de los aranceles indica que están interesados en reducir las tensiones.
resumen:
Scott Bessent, secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, indicó que depende de Pekín dar el primer paso para reducir la escalada arancelaria, debido al desequilibrio comercial entre ambos países.
Bessent afirmó en una entrevista para CNBC que China debe desescalar, porque Estados Unidos le vende cinco veces menos de lo que China le vende, por lo que los aranceles del 125% son insostenibles.
Bessent afirmó que el hecho de que China haya eximido a algunos productos de los aranceles indica que están interesados en reducir las tensiones.
Bessent añadió que tiene “una escalera de escalada en la recámara y estamos muy ansiosos por no tener que utilizarla”, y que la escalada podría incluir un embargo.
El secretario del Tesoro también señaló que Estados Unidos ha dejado de lado a China por ahora, mientras busca acuerdos comerciales con 15 y 17 países más.
Bessent añadió que no le sorprendería que un acuerdo comercial con India fuera el primero en anunciarse.
Funcionarios estadounidenses se reunieron con sus homólogos chinos durante las reuniones del FMI y el Banco Mundial en Washington, DC, la semana pasada para hablar sobre “estabilidad financiera”, pero no indicó que surgieran discusiones comerciales durante las conversaciones.

title: Global news wrap: 100 days of Trump, monetary polices, Pope’s passing
content: The first 100 days of Donald Trump’s second term have been marked by policy moves that led to turbulence in both domestic and global markets. Meanwhile, central banks in the US, UK, Japan and ...
resumen:
The first 100 days of Donald Trump’s second term have been marked by policy moves that led to turbulence in both domestic and global markets.

Since Trump’s return to office on 20 January, the dollar index has fallen nearly 9%, its worst performance in the first 100 days of any presidency since the Nixon era.

Central banks in the US, UK, Japan and Indonesia will announce their monetary policies next month.

The first 100 days of Donald Trump’s second term as US President have been marked by a whirlwind of economic policies that have created uncertainty in global markets.

Since Trump’s return to office on 20 January, the dollar index has fallen nearly 9%, its worst performance in the first 100 days of any presidency since the Nixon era, when the US abandoned the Bretton Woods system.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has ruled out a recession in the world’s largest economy.

As several central banks gear up for their monetary policy reviews in May, markets are largely anticipating a cautious tone.

The US Federal Reserve faces mounting political pressure from President Donald Trump to cut rates.

In Japan, the central bank is expected to keep rates steady, wary of a weakening yen and external shocks, even as domestic inflation inches closer to its 2% target.

The Bank of England and Bank Indonesia are also expected to hold policy rates unchanged.

California's economy grew 6.01% in 2024.

As of March 2025, the state’s unemployment rate stood at 5.3%, higher than the national average of 4.2%.

The IMF has raised alarms about rising global debt, forecasting a significant increase in the coming years.

According to its April 2025 Fiscal Monitor, global public debt is set to rise by 2.8 percentage points in 2025 to 95.1% of GDP.

In the US, debt could rise to 122.5% of GDP in 2025.

China's debt is expected to rise to 96.3% of GDP, while India's is projected to reach 80.4%.

The passing of Pope Francis has brought an end to a 12-year-long papacy.

At the time of his death, Pope Francis was the second-oldest pope to serve in over 400 years.

title: Canada federal election 2025 live updates and results: Polls close nationwide as Canadians await historic outcome
content: Canadians have officially finished voting for which party will form the country's next government, with the final polling stations closing at 10 p.m. EST in Yukon and British Columbia. Election ...
resumen:
The Liberal Party of Canada under Mark Carney is projected to form the next government. The party secured enough votes to edge out challenges from the Conservative Party of Canada and their leader Pierre Poilievre. Carney spoke at a Liberal election party in Ottawa, calling for a united Canada.

The New Democratic Party saw their voter turnout plummet on April 28, and it appears unlikely that the NDP will secure enough seats to maintain official party status. Jagmeet Singh announced that he will officially resign as party leader after eight years in the role.

Results across Canada’s 343 ridings are being counted, which will dictate whether the Liberals form a majority or minority government for their fourth consecutive term. In order to secure a majority, the Liberals need 172 seats in the House of Commons.

The win for the Liberals follows the resignation of former prime minister Justin Trudeau and the prorogation of Parliament in January 2025.

Pierre Poilievre conceded defeat and accepted that the Liberals will form the next government.

Jagmeet Singh told a room full of NDP supporters on election night: "I will be stepping down as party leader as soon as an interim leader is selected."

At least seven NDP MPs have lost their seats and Leader Jagmeet Singh's is in a tough fight in his own seat in British Columbia. The party held 24 seats at dissolution and needs 12 for official party status but is leading or elected in just eight as of midnight EDT.

Voters on Canada's East Coast delivered a steady-as-she-goes endorsement to the incumbent Liberals on Monday, as the party held on to its commanding position in the region. The Liberals were elected or leading in 23 of the 32 ridings, and the Conservatives were at nine.

Elizabeth May is projected to retain her British Columbia riding while Jonathan Pedneault has been defeated in the Montreal seat of Outremont.

Liberal Leader Mark Carney has also won his Ottawa riding of Nepean.

Bloc Québécois Leader Yves-François Blanchet has won his Quebec riding of Beloeil-Chambly.

The Liberals are leading in 22 of the 32 ridings where polls have closed, while in the 2021 election, the Liberals took 24 of 32 seats in the region. Six seats went to the Conservatives and another six undetermined. The Liberals are leading with 52 per cent of votes, compared to 21 per cent for the Conservatives.

Three of Liberal Leader Mark Carney's cabinet ministers have been re-elected: Joanne Thompson in St. John's East, N.L., Kody Blois in Kings—Hants, N.S., and Dominic LeBlanc in Beauséjour, N.B.

The Liberals have won the ridings of Avalon and Cape Spear. The Conservatives have won the ridings of Central Newfoundland and Long Range Mountains.

NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh is in his home riding of Burnaby Central waiting to learn his party's fate — and his own. A political party needs at least 12 members in the House of Commons to be a “recognized party" in parliamentary proceedings.

resumen: The article discusses the limitations of monetary policy, particularly in the context of the current economic situation. It argues that bad economic policies, such as those related to trade, can outweigh the effects of monetary policy. title: Los BRICS debaten en Brasil su respuesta a la guerra arancelaria declarada por Trump
content: El canciller Vieira, el anfitrión, insta al bloque del sur global a centrarse en la defensa del multilateralismo sin ser “un bloque de enfrentamiento” ...
resumen:
Los BRICS debaten en Río de Janeiro una respuesta coordinada a la guerra arancelaria declarada por el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, y el consiguiente caos comercial. El bloque celebra una de sus primeras reuniones de cancilleres desde que se amplió de cinco a 11 socios. El canciller brasileño, Mauro Vieira, ha instado a sus colegas a que los BRICS sean “una fuerza de paz, no un bloque de enfrentamiento”, una alianza que refuerce los principios del derecho internacional y la reforma de los organismos multilaterales. Brasil suele insistir en que los BRICS no son contra nadie, sino que son un espacio de cooperación y desarrollo.

El principal negociador brasileño, el embajador Mauricio Lyrio, explicó antes del encuentro que “los ministros negocian una declaración para reafirmar la centralidad de las negociaciones comerciales multilaterales como eje principal de acción en el comercio” y que “reafirmarán su crítica a las medidas unilaterales de cualquier origen, una postura sostenida desde hace tiempo por los países BRICS”. Lyrio evitó mencionar a Estados Unidos, a Trump o la batería que gravámenes que ha impuesto a decenas de naciones y que se ceban, especialmente, en China, México y Canadá.

En la reunión participan Brasil, Rusia, India, China, Sudáfrica y los recién incorporados, en 2023, Arabia Saudí (que no ha enviado representante), Indonesia, Irán, Emiratos Árabes Unidos, Egipto, Etiopía. Han asistido los cancilleres ruso, Sergéi Lavrov, y chino, Wang Yi, pero varias de las delegaciones han sido encabezadas por diplomáticos de menor rango.

Desde que Trump amenazó a los BRICS con imponerles gravámenes de entre el 100% y el 150% a sus productos si adoptaban una divisa propia en sustitución del dólar, el bloque de países del Sur ha aparcado la idea. Avanzan en su estrategia de intensificar las transacciones entre sí en sus propias divisas y, de paso, dar la espalda al dólar. El canciller Lavrov, de Rusia, destaca que la participación del rublo y de las monedas de países amigos alcanzó el 90% en las transacciones de Rusia con los países BRICS en 2024.

En los últimos años, países como Rusia o Irán han ido creando senderos comerciales alternativos al dólar y al sistema bancario Swift para sortear las sanciones occidentales.

El presidente brasileño, Luiz Ináco Lula da Silva, viaja a China y Rusia el mes siguiente.

Brasil y la Unión Europea coinciden en que la coyuntura actual ofrece una excelente oportunidad de ratificar el pacto Mercosur-UE. El ministro de Finanzas brasileño, Fernando Haddad, ha afirmado que ve mayor disposición, en especial de Francia, a cerrar definitivamente el acuerdo.

Vieira ha reiterado, en el discurso de apertura, la necesidad urgente de resolver mediante negociaciones las guerras de Gaza y Ucrania. La reunión se celebra en el palacio de Itamaraty original, que fue la sede del Ministerio de Exteriores hasta el traslado a Brasilia, en 1960.

title: Reality check on US-China talks
content: President Donald Trump claims that trade negotiations will soon deliver a deal with China. But officials in Beijing and Washington are casting doubt on that assessment.
resumen:
President Donald Trump claims that trade negotiations will soon deliver a deal with China.

Canadians are hitting the polls this morning to elect a new leader in a race heavily shaped by Trump’s trade threats.

Trump said tariff revenue and the External Revenue Service could help eliminate taxes on people who make less than $200,000 a year.

President Donald Trump claims tariff talks with China are moving quickly, as fears mount over the economic fallout of a prolonged stalemate.

The U.S. slapped a whopping 145 percent tariff on China.

Trump insists that negotiations are progressing, and told reporters earlier this month that a deal could be reached with China within three to four weeks.

Trump was quoted in TIME as saying that Xi had called him to discuss trade.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent told ABC News’ Martha Raddatz in an interview on Sunday: “I don’t know if President Trump has spoken with President Xi.”

A poll from the Washington Post-ABC News-Ipsos released Sunday found that more than seven in 10 Americans rate the economy as “not so good” or “poor,” and 53 percent say economic conditions have worsened since Trump returned to office in January.

Bessent spoke with Chinese officials last week during the spring meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins said that talks between U.S. and Chinese officials were taking place “every day” in an interview Sunday with CNN’s “State of the Union.”

China has said that formal talks on Trump’s latest tariffs have not officially started.

Trump also told TIME that he’s negotiated 200 trade deals with countries that are seeking to stave off the return of so-called reciprocal tariffs in July.

Rollins said there are “100 countries that are knocking on the door.”

Bessent acknowledged negotiations with only a handful of countries. “There’s 17 important trading partners, and we have a process in place, over the next 90 days, to negotiate with them, especially the – with the Asian countries,” he said on Sunday.

Canadians are hitting the polls today for federal elections that have been heavily shaped by Trump’s tariff threats and claims of wanting to make Canada the 51st state in the union, reports POLITICO’s Jonathan Martin.

The contest is coming down to the Liberal Party’s Mark Carney and Pierre Poilievre of the Conservative Party, who held a significant 26-point advantage in late 2024.

Now, Carney enjoys a narrow lead over his conservative rival.

Trump agreed on Saturday to meet with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.

Trump said his tariff plans could help eliminate taxes on people who make less than $200,000 a year.

The Trump administration claims to have collected nearly $16 billion during the month of April in “customs and excise taxes,” according to data from the Treasury Department.

The Senate Finance Committee is holding a hearing on Wednesday for Trump’s nominee to lead U.S. Customs and Border Protection, Rodney Scott, Chair Mike Crapo (R-Idaho) announced last week.

title: República Dominicana, en buena posición para renegociar aranceles con EE. UU.
content: El canciller de la República Dominicana, Roberto Álvarez, afirmó este lunes que el país tiene un excedente comercial con los Estados Unidos, logrando estar en una posición "buena" para una negociación ...
resumen:
El canciller de la República Dominicana, Roberto Álvarez, afirmó que el país tiene un excedente comercial con los Estados Unidos, logrando estar en una posición "buena" para una negociación respecto al arancel impuesto por ese país a los productos dominicanos a principios de abril.

Álvarez confirmó que el embajador y representante Comercial de Estados Unidos, Jamieson Greer, declaró durante la reunión que tuvieron el pasado martes 22 de abril en Washington, que República Dominicana está entre los países "que mejores se comportan".

Álvarez expresó que el embajador Greer dijo: "Miren, realmente ustedes son el país, están entre los países que mejores se comportan. Ustedes tienen la tarifa mínima (10 %) porque es la tarifa global".

Álvarez participó en la reunión como parte de la delegación oficial, que además integraron los ministros de Hacienda, Jochi Vicente, y el de Industria y Comercio, Víctor -Ito- Bisonó.

El canciller confirmó que hay que esperar, no sabe cuánto tiempo, ya que es un proceso de negociación continuo que desde que salieron de la reunión la semana pasada se ha mantenido.

Álvarez dijo que esperan que, en las próximas semanas, más tardar meses, puedan resolver este tema.

En el marco de las nuevas disposiciones del gobierno de Donald Trump, se explicó que el arancel aplicado a productos dominicanos será del 10 %, dentro de un enfoque global del comercio internacional.

title: Trump’s trade war puts Singapore’s economic growth, jobs and wages at risk, says MAS
content: Inflation, which is already down to a four-year low, will remain modest amid weakening growth outlook Read more at straitstimes.com. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen:
The raft of tariffs announced by US President Donald Trump and the uncertainty over the extent of damage they will cause across the global economy will depress economic and wage growth in trade-driven Singapore, said the Republic’s central bank.

In its quarterly macroeconomic review released on April 28, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) maintained the zero per cent to 2 per cent growth forecast, but warned that prolonged trade conflicts could pose further downside risks to the country.

The weakening growth outlook will, however, keep inflation – already at a four-year low – modest, with both core and all-items inflation averaging between 0.5 per cent and 1.5 per cent in 2025.

Singapore’s core inflation, which excludes private transport and accommodation costs to better reflect the expenses of households here, eased to 0.5 per cent year on year in March – its lowest level since March 2021.

While the challenging global trade environment will hit job prospects in trade-related sectors of manufacturing and wholesale trade disproportionately, most firms are likely to pull back on their hiring and expansion plans amid the economic uncertainty, dragging down employment growth for a wider array of sectors, MAS said.

The Ministry of Manpower’s preliminary data for the first quarter of 2025, also released on April 28, showed the unemployment rate has ticked up slightly while employment growth slowed from the previous quarter.

MAS said: “Further, heightened geopolitical and trade policy uncertainty poses additional downside risks to Singapore’s small and trade-dependent economy, and consequently jobs and livelihoods.”

In concert with the deteriorating global growth outlook, economic activity in Singapore has been showing signs of softening since the beginning of 2025.

Singapore’s seasonally adjusted gross domestic product (GDP) contracted by 0.8 per cent quarter on quarter in the first three months of 2025, a pullback from the 0.5 per cent expansion in the last quarter of 2024.

MAS said: “While there are nascent indications of economic softening at the sectoral level, these weaknesses have yet to become deeply entrenched or pervasive.”

However, the central bank noted: “Prolonged trade tensions could pose downside risks to growth, through further disruptions in trade flows, undermining business investments and dampening global demand.“Conversely, trade tensions may de-escalate over time, which could boost sentiments and export activity.”

MAS said that activity in trade-related clusters has cooled even as global indicators continued to suggest some pre-tariff front-loading and firm electronics demand.

For instance, key indicators such as US imports of electronics and global chip sales recorded strong growth in the first two months of 2025.

Still, Singapore’s industrial production moderated to a 4 per cent year-on-year growth in the first quarter of 2025, down from 5.5 per cent in the fourth quarter of 2024. This is mainly weighed down by slower activity in the electronics cluster.

Overall, non-oil export growth has eased over this period, reflecting weakness in the non-electronics segment as well, MAS said.

The central bank said that amid significant uncertainty around US trade policy and its impact, global GDP growth is expected to slow to between 2 per cent and 2.5 per cent in 2025, from 3.2 per cent in 2024.

“Global growth could slip further if the US broadens and intensifies the tariffs to include other specific products such as semiconductors and pharmaceuticals,” MAS said.

It added: “Retaliatory actions by its trading partners will exacerbate the impact on growth. Market sentiments also remain fragile, and further shocks could trigger disorderly price adjustments, with the ensuing tightening in financial conditions compounding the downturn.”

MAS explained at length how the US tariffs announced on April 2 will affect the local economy both directly and indirectly, even as Singapore is subject to a baseline levy of 10 per cent – much lower than that for China, for instance, which is subject to the so-called reciprocal tariffs of 145 per cent.

The US also announced harsh reciprocal tariffs on a host of other countries including close allies such as the European Union and Japan.

However, on April 9, a 90-day pause was announced on the higher-band tariffs except those imposed on China. Meanwhile, the baseline tariff and the 25 per cent sectoral levies on all US imports of steel, aluminium, and automobiles and parts remain in place.

MAS said the US is Singapore’s second-largest market, accounting for 11 per cent of its domestic exports in 2024.

Products subject to the baseline tariff account for about 55 per cent of Singapore’s domestic exports to the US, with product-specific tariffs on steel, aluminium, and automobiles and parts comprising a much smaller share of around 5 per cent.

While semiconductors, consumer electronics and pharmaceutical goods – which account for about 40 per cent of Singapore’s domestic exports to the US – are currently not subject to tariffs, the US has initiated trade probes into imports of these goods on national security concerns and could impose restrictions in the coming months, MAS warned.

It added that reciprocal tariffs will also be indirectly transmitted to Singapore through its trade linkages with other countries hit by them.

This indirect exposure can be proxied by Singapore’s value added embedded in US imports from partner economies.

Value added refers to the amount of value created in a product by a specific country, from the point of view of the entire supply chain. In essence, it represents the contribution of a country’s factors of production – land, labour, capital – to the final product.

With reciprocal tariffs on other countries on hold for now, the immediate impact of the levy will come from China, which is Singapore’s largest export market and also accounts for an important share in US imports, which are currently subject to the exceptionally high tariff rate.

“The intermediate goods and services that Singapore exports to China are used in the latter’s goods exports to the US,” said MAS.

There are other indirect spillovers through regional economies including those via Asean, given Singapore’s importance in production and trading supply chains that leverage its hub role in areas such as transport and financial services.

MAS said trade conflicts hurt global growth as economies that levy duties on imports suffer an increase in costs, which in turn weigh on business and consumer spending. Meanwhile, exporting countries that have been hit by tariffs will experience a negative external demand shock.

The ongoing global uncertainties are also likely to further dampen the already-moderating electronics cycle, MAS said, citing a December 2024 forecast by the World Semiconductor Trade Statistics.

The non-profit data provider had projected that global chip sales growth will moderate to 11.2 per cent in 2025 from 20 per cent in 2024.

Still, demand driven by artificial intelligence will provide some underlying support to the global semiconductor industry, according to MAS, because the shift towards more advanced and costly algorithms will mean a greater need for high-performance hardware.

title: Trump’s first 100 days: Steamrolling government, strong-arming allies, igniting trade wars
content: In his first 100 days, President Donald Trump exerted his power in a sweep and scale that has no easy historical comparison.
resumen:
In his first 100 days, President Donald Trump exerted his power in a sweep and scale that has no easy historical comparison. His actions target the architecture of the New Deal and the Great Society, and he is also rewriting the Reagan Republican orthodoxy of free trade and strong international alliances. To implement parts of his vision, he deployed Elon Musk to dismantle the federal workforce. Trump has unilaterally declared the power to remake the post-World War II alliance with Europe. The Republican president has made extraordinary emergency declarations to rewrite the rules of global trade and has ordered the removal of migrants to a prison in El Salvador without judicial review. He has taken direct aim at law, media, public health and culture.

Economy: Trump has tried to bend the U.S. economy to his will. Consumer confidence has plummeted, stock markets have convulsed and investors are losing confidence in the credibility of Trump’s policies.

Immigration: Trump has implemented some of the hardest-line immigration policies in the nation’s history. Trump invoked the Alien Enemies Act of 1798 to deport migrants with limited due process, then used it to send hundreds of alleged Venezuelan gang members to a mega-prison in El Salvador in defiance of a court order.

Retribution: Trump made actions taking aim at the prosecutors who investigated him and the law firms that employed them. He went after former officials who criticized him or asserted that he had lost the 2020 presidential election to Democrat Joe Biden. Trump ordered the suspension of the security clearances of the more than four dozen former intelligence officials who signed onto a letter during the 2020 campaign. Trump’s Justice Department fired the prosecutors who investigated him as part of special counsel Jack Smith’s team and demanded the names of FBI agents who participated in investigations into the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol.

Courts, judges and the rule of law: Trump’s executive orders reshaping the federal government are facing more than 150 lawsuits. Judges have ruled against the administration dozens of times. The administration has also pushed back in court, quickly appealing multiple orders to the conservative-majority Supreme Court.

Diplomacy and international relations: Trump has rejected the post-World War II order. He has rejected long-standing alliances and hinted at scaling back the U.S. troop presence in Europe. Trump also pledged a swift end to the wars in Ukraine and Gaza. He has repeatedly called for the U.S. to annex Greenland, to retake control of the Panama Canal and to make Canada the 51st U.S. state.

Congress: Trump is testing, challenging and even bullying the Congress in unparalleled ways.

Military: The Pentagon has been rocked by the removals of top military leadership, including its only female four-star officers, its Joint Chiefs chairman — a Black general — and its top military lawyers. Trump has said the military had gone “woke” and he acted swiftly to reverse long-standing policies. He issued an executive order to remove transgender service members, which has been stalled by the courts. Hegseth ordered the military to eliminate any programming, books or imagery that celebrates diversity.

Public health: At the Department of Health and Human Services, 10,000 jobs are gone. Billions of dollars in research sent to scientists and universities was shut off. Public meetings to discuss flu shots and other vaccines have been canceled. Fluoride in drinking water may be the next to go, according to Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Kennedy’s resistance to launching a vaccination campaign as a growing measles outbreak has worsened, so far infecting hundreds and leaving two young children dead, has elicited concerns from doctors, public health experts and lawmakers.

Energy and environment: Trump has reversed Biden’s focus on slowing climate change to pursue what the Republican calls U.S. “energy dominance” in the global market. Trump withdrew the U.S. from the Paris climate agreement, but he has moved even more aggressively in his second term to roll back major environmental regulations.

Arts and culture: Trump has ousted leaders, placed staff on administrative leave and cut off hundreds of millions of dollars in funding that artists, libraries, museums, theaters and others in the cultural community had long counted on.

Media: The new administration has aggressively, even innovatively, waged combat against the press since taking office. It has fought against CBS News and The Associated Press in court, sought to dismantle the government-run Voice of America and sent the Federal Communications Commission after perceived media rivals. The White House has established rapid-response social media feeds that maintain a constant flow of rejoinders to “hold the fake news accountable.” The AP sued the administration after it reduced the outlet’s access to presidential events for not following Trump’s lead in renaming the Gulf of Mexico, winning a court ruling that the government could not punish the organization for free speech.

content: He has launched an unprecedented global tariff war and slashed US foreign aid. He has disparaged Nato allies and embraced Russia’s narrative about ...

In the first 100 days of his second term, US President Donald Trump's "America First" agenda has alienated friends and emboldened adversaries. He has launched a global tariff war, slashed US foreign aid, disparaged NATO allies, embraced Russia's narrative about its invasion of Ukraine, and spoken about annexing Greenland, retaking the Panama Canal, and making Canada the 51st state.

Elliott Abrams, a conservative who served under Presidents Ronald Reagan and George W. Bush, stated that Trump is much more radical now than he was eight years ago.

Trump's actions have unnerved some governments, leading them to respond in ways that could be difficult to undo.

Critics see signs of democratic backsliding at home, including verbal attacks on judges, a pressure campaign against universities, and the transfer of migrants to an El Salvador prison.

Dennis Ross, a former Middle East negotiator for Democratic and Republican administrations, stated that there is a huge disruption in world affairs.

Reuters interviews with more than a dozen current and former government officials, foreign diplomats, and independent analysts in Washington and capitals around the world suggest that the situation may not be beyond repair if Trump softens his approach.

Some European allies are looking to boost their own defense industries. Debate has intensified in South Korea about developing its own nuclear arsenal.

The White House rejects the notion that Trump has hurt US credibility. White House National Security Council spokesman Brian Hughes stated that Trump is taking swift action to address challenges.

A Reuters/Ipsos poll released on March 13 indicates that more than half of Americans, including one in four Republicans, think Trump is “too closely aligned” with Russia.

Experts say the future of a global system based on free trade, rule of law, and respect for territorial integrity is at stake.

Trump has set in motion a sweeping tariffs policy, reversed US policy on Russia’s war in Ukraine, and engaged in an Oval Office shouting match with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy.

German Chancellor Friedrich Merz expressed concern about European relations with the United States.

Trump has employed expansionist rhetoric, including saying the US will “get” Greenland, that Canada should become part of the US, threatening to seize the Panama Canal, and proposing that Washington take over Gaza.

Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen stated that Trump's actions are about the world order that has been built together across the Atlantic over generations.

The European Union has prepared retaliatory tariffs. Some countries such as Germany and France are looking at spending more on their militaries. Canada is seeking to strengthen economic and security links to Europe.

South Korea has vowed to try to work with Trump and preserve the alliance.

A senior Japanese government official close to Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba stated that Japan was taken by surprise by the magnitude of Trump’s tariffs.

Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez met with President Xi Jinping in Beijing.

Aaron David Miller, a former veteran US diplomat, said it’s not too late for Trump to shift course on foreign policy.

title: Inflation, Trump's Tariffs, Climate, Immigration And More | Key Issues At Stake For Canada Elections 2025
content: Canadians head to the polls in 2025 amid a trade war with the United States, a housing crisis, and the fallout of record-breaking wildfires. The election will decide how Canada navigates key issues of ...
resumen:
Canadians head to the polls in an election shaped by economic and geopolitical pressures. Donald Trump's renewed tariffs have triggered a trade war with the country’s largest trading partner. The cost of living has risen faster than wages for the third consecutive year. Wildfires across Alberta and British Columbia have laid bare the country's vulnerabilities to climate change. Voters are choosing between starkly different proposals on how to defend Canada's economic sovereignty, rebuild social protections, and navigate a new era of global uncertainty.

Inflation remains a searing concern for Canadians, as the cost of food, fuel, and basic goods has soared in the past two years. The Conservative Party, under Pierre Poilievre, has made the cost of living the centrepiece of its campaign, promising to "axe the carbon tax," lower income taxes, and deregulate sectors to ease consumer prices. The Liberals, now under Mark Carney's leadership, are pitching a more tempered strategy: targeted tax credits for low- and middle-income Canadians and direct supports for families most affected by inflation. The New Democratic Party (NDP), led by Jagmeet Singh, frames the crisis as a product of "corporate greed," pushing for a windfall tax on large corporations that have posted record profits during inflationary surges. The Green Party argues that true economic security lies in overhauling the economy toward sustainable industries, reducing Canadians' dependence on volatile fossil fuel markets.

Canada's housing crisis has reached a new peak. In cities like Toronto, Vancouver, and Montreal, home ownership is increasingly out of reach for young Canadians, while rental prices are skyrocketing. Poilievre has promised to free up federal land for housing and drastically cut building regulations. Carney's Liberals are proposing an ambitious national housing strategy that includes incentives for affordable rental construction and a first-time homebuyer support program. The NDP advocates for the construction of 500,000 affordable homes over the next decade and stricter measures to curb real estate speculation by foreign buyers. The Bloc Québécois, while focused mainly on Quebec, proposes increased provincial control over housing policy to address regional disparities.

Public healthcare, a longstanding source of Canadian national pride, is straining under the weight of staff shortages, high patient volume, and an ageing population. The NDP promises an ambitious expansion with universal pharmacare and dental care. The Liberals, under Carney, propose conditional funding to provinces, aimed at reducing wait times and improving frontline care. Poilievre proposes that provinces should be given greater autonomy over healthcare delivery, coupled with federal funding. The Greens call for a "health-in-all-policies" approach that tackles environmental and social determinants of health, not just medical care.

The defining question of this campaign is how Canada will navigate its deteriorating relationship with the United States. Trump's tariffs on Canadian steel, aluminium, and agricultural goods—paired with incendiary remarks about Canada becoming the "51st State"—have rattled the political establishment. Most parties agree on retaliatory tariffs, but differ on strategy. Poilievre’s Conservatives propose using tariff revenues for direct tax relief for workers. Carney's Liberals propose financial support for affected industries, C$5 billion for infrastructure upgrades, and C$2 billion to safeguard the auto sector. Singh’s NDP promises to funnel every dollar raised toward relief efforts and has threatened a 100% tariff on Tesla products if escalation continues. The Bloc Québécois calls for pandemic-style support packages, particularly for Quebec’s struggling aluminium industry. Both the Conservatives and Liberals vow to dismantle internal trade barriers, while Poilievre is pitching a "Commonwealth trade and mobility agreement" with the UK, Australia, and New Zealand.

The wildfires that devastated large parts of Alberta and British Columbia last summer have thrust climate change back into the national spotlight. The Greens and the NDP are pushing for an emergency-level response: ending fossil fuel subsidies, halting new oil and gas projects, and investing heavily in renewable energy. The NDP matches this urgency with a pledge to phase out fossil fuels by 2035. Carney's Liberals maintain their commitment to net-zero emissions by 2050. Poilievre’s Conservatives acknowledge climate change but favour a technology-driven response, particularly carbon capture initiatives, over carbon pricing mechanisms. They propose reducing regulation to boost the economy and also want to remove the cap on oil and gas emissions, effectively ending Bill C-69, an environmental assessment act for major infrastructure.

Immigration remains a divisive topic, sharpened by recent controversies over the Khalistan movement's activities within Canada. Following India's diplomatic fallout with Canada over alleged interference, the issue of how to manage diasporic politics has become entangled with immigration debates. The Liberals defend Canada’s multicultural policies while committing to crack down on any groups engaged in violent extremism. Poilievre’s Conservatives have taken a harder line, promising greater scrutiny of immigration processes and stronger laws against foreign political interference. The NDP maintains a pro-immigration stance, focusing on immigrant rights and social integration.

This election is not merely about economic policy, healthcare funding, or housing. It is about how Canada defines itself in a changing world order where democracies are backsliding, and climate disasters are becoming routine. Canadians today are voting for a government that will face immediate pressure to stabilise relations with the United States, to rebuild trust in public services, and to define whether Canada's future lies in closer alliances abroad or renewed protections at home.

El secretario del Tesoro, Scott Bessent, dijo el domingo que no sabía si el presidente Trump había hablado con el presidente Xi Jinping de China, lo que generó más dudas sobre la reciente sugerencia del Sr. Trump de que el Sr. Xi lo había llamado.

El secretario intentó aliviar las preocupaciones sobre las tensiones comerciales con China y otros países, insistiendo en que la administración estaba en conversaciones con varias naciones y reconociendo que los aranceles que ha impuesto a los productos chinos no eran sostenibles.

Pero parece que la comunicación con China ha sido mínima.

"No sé si el presidente Trump ha hablado con el presidente Xi", dijo el Sr. Bessent cuando la presentadora, Martha Raddatz, le preguntó sobre las declaraciones del Sr. Trump de que los dos líderes habían hablado sobre comercio. "Sé que tienen una muy buena relación y mucho respeto mutuo".

El secretario del Tesoro es tradicionalmente el funcionario estadounidense que lidera las conversaciones económicas entre Estados Unidos y China y se esperaría que supiera si el Sr. Trump y el Sr. Xi habían participado en tales discusiones.

En una entrevista con Time la semana pasada, el Sr. Trump dijo que el Sr. Xi lo había llamado, aunque se negó a decir cuándo, y afirmó que su equipo estaba en conversaciones activas con China sobre un acuerdo comercial.

Cuando se le preguntó sobre la entrevista fuera de la Casa Blanca el viernes, el presidente reiteró que había hablado con el presidente chino "numerosas veces", pero se negó a responder cuando se le preguntó si había ocurrido alguna llamada después de que impuso aranceles este mes.

Beijing ha negado que las conversaciones estuvieran en curso. "China y Estados Unidos no han mantenido consultas ni negociaciones sobre el tema de los aranceles", dijo Guo Jiakun, el portavoz del Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores de China, en una conferencia de prensa el viernes. "Estados Unidos no debería confundir al público".

El Sr. Bessent dijo en la entrevista del domingo que interactuó con sus homólogos chinos la semana pasada durante las reuniones de primavera del Fondo Monetario Internacional y el Banco Mundial, pero sugirió que las conversaciones fueron "más sobre las cosas tradicionales como la estabilidad financiera, las alertas tempranas económicas globales".

Hablando con los reporteros al margen de esas reuniones la semana pasada, el Sr. Bessent desestimó la especulación de que el Sr. Trump estaba considerando unilateralmente la reducción de los aranceles que ha impuesto a China antes de cualquier negociación con el Sr. Xi. El Sr. Bessent enfatizó que cualquier medida para reducir las tensiones comerciales debe ser mutua.

"No creo que ninguna de las partes crea que los niveles arancelarios actuales son sostenibles", dijo en ese momento. El secretario agregó: "Esto es el equivalente a un embargo, y una ruptura entre los dos países en el comercio no conviene a los intereses de nadie".

Los aranceles estadounidenses sobre China ya han comenzado a afectar a los importadores estadounidenses. Se espera que el dolor se intensifique esta semana cuando una laguna que permite a los minoristas enviar ropa y otros bienes de China directamente a los compradores estadounidenses sin pagar aranceles expire el viernes.

title: Real World Economics: The buck stops Trump, or so it appears
content: President Donald Trump has backed off from his threats against Fed Chair Jerome Powell. He has softened his tone on trade with China, alternately suggesting he would be “flexible” and “very nice” ...
resumen: President Donald Trump has backed off from his threats against Fed Chair Jerome Powell. He has softened his tone on trade with China, alternately suggesting he would be “flexible” and “very nice” and yet also repeating threats. China has not yet budged from its harsh first responses. Prices of stocks and bonds, along with long-term interest rates, have oscillated up and down in response to the daily verbal sallies from the White House. Prices of major foreign currencies have also varied — almost entirely up in terms of their value of the dollar. It takes 9.1% more dollars to buy a euro than it did on Trump’s Inauguration Day; 7.8% more to buy a British pound, 9.2% more for a Japanese yen. However, the Canadian dollar is only 3.5% more expensive in our currency and the Chinese renminbi exchange rate has barely budged at all. Changes in the value of one currency versus another are more important than most Americans understand. A “strong,” or high-priced, currency makes its nation’s exports expensive to world buyers while rendering imports cheap. It effectively subsidizes imports and taxes exports. This is good for consumers who want to buy cheap goods. But it punishes domestic producers — farmers, miners, mill and factory owners — along with people who work for them, because in a global supply chain, U.S. export customers can shop for a better price from countries with “weaker” currencies. Trump Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, erstwhile adviser Steve Bannon and other Trump whisperers argue that beyond raising tariffs, we need to make it more difficult for trade-surplus nations like China to invest dollars in U.S. bonds. That would drive down the value of the dollar, reduce U.S. imports and increase employment and output here. But, like tariffs, it also would raise inflation.

title: La falsa promesa de los aranceles
content: Para cuestionar eficazmente la lógica que subyace a la agenda proteccionista de la administración estadounidense, primero debemos entenderla de forma clara y concreta.
resumen:
En esta era de creciente proteccionismo, es urgente explicar los costos de una guerra comercial, que amenaza con acelerar la fragmentación de la economía global.

El régimen arancelario de la administración Trump se sostiene sobre cuatro argumentos:

1.  Los aranceles son una herramienta para aumentar los ingresos públicos, específicamente, para ayudar a reducir el déficit presupuestario de Estados Unidos, que muchos economistas consideran insostenible. La Oficina de Presupuesto del Congreso prevé que el déficit federal, actualmente del 6,4% del PIB, se mantendrá por encima del 6% hasta 2035. El secretario del Tesoro, Scott Bessent, se ha comprometido a reducir el déficit fiscal al 3% del PIB para 2028, utilizando los ingresos arancelarios como herramienta principal. Con la imposición de aranceles, el gobierno de Estados Unidos generaría ingresos procedentes de bienes importados que actualmente están exentos de impuestos federales. El gobierno de Estados Unidos también deja de percibir ingresos por el impuesto sobre la renta y el impuesto corporativo que se habrían recaudado si esos mismos bienes y servicios se hubieran producido en Estados Unidos.
2.  Los aranceles se centran en la reciprocidad. Sus defensores sostienen que, mientras que las exportaciones estadounidenses suelen estar sujetas a aranceles e impuestos elevados, los bienes importados enfrentan pocas barreras, o ninguna, al ingresar a Estados Unidos.
3.  Los aranceles protegerán a las industrias nacionales y ayudarán a restaurar la base manufacturera de Estados Unidos, que ha sido vaciada por décadas de acuerdos de libre comercio que trasladaron la producción a países de bajo costo como México, India y China.
4.  Los aranceles se presentan a menudo como un medio para reequilibrar la economía y redistribuir los frutos de la globalización, que han beneficiado desproporcionadamente al capital por sobre el trabajo. Los defensores de los aranceles argumentan que Estados Unidos se ha vuelto peligrosamente dependiente de unas cadenas de suministro mundiales frágiles y poco fiables.

Los aranceles aumentan el costo de los bienes importados, lo que supone una carga desproporcionada para los hogares de bajos ingresos. El gobierno puede recaudar menos ingresos de lo esperado si los consumidores evitan las importaciones y se decantan por productos fabricados en Estados Unidos. Los aranceles de Trump ya han desencadenado una escalada de represalias, sobre todo con China, que tuvo un superávit comercial de casi 300.000 millones de dólares con Estados Unidos en 2024. El uso de aranceles para proteger la fabricación estadounidense requiere enormes subsidios gubernamentales para reconstruir y apoyar a las industrias nacionales no competitivas. La Ley Arancelaria Smoot-Hawley de 1930, que impuso aranceles a decenas de miles de importaciones a Estados Unidos, agravó la Gran Depresión.

title: EEUU amenaza con restringir de nuevo la importación de vacuno mexicano por el gusano barrenador
content: La secretaria de Agricultura de Estados Unidos, Brooke Rollins, ha remitido este sábado una carta al Gobierno mexicano en la que advierte de que restringirán de nuevo las importaciones de productos ...
resumen:
La secretaria de Agricultura de Estados Unidos, Brooke Rollins, ha remitido una carta al Gobierno mexicano en la que advierte de que restringirán de nuevo las importaciones de productos animales de México si no se intensifica la lucha contra una plaga de cochliomyia hominivorax o gusano barrenador antes del próximo miércoles.

Rollins ha publicado la misiva en su cuenta en X en la que reprocha a México que haya limitado a seis días a la semana los vuelos de fumigación contra la plaga y que haya impuesto "aranceles aduaneros onerosos" sobre las piezas necesarias para el mantenimiento de los aviones de la empresa responsable del tratamiento.

El gusano barrenador puede infectar al ganado, la fauna silvestre y, en raras ocasiones, a las personas.

En marzo Estados Unidos importó 24.000 cabezas de ganado de México, una cifra inferior a las 114.000 del mismo periodo del año anterior, según datos del Departamento de Agricultura de Estados Unidos.

Estados Unidos bloqueó los envíos de ganado mexicano a finales de noviembre tras el descubrimiento de la plaga. Levantó la restricción en febrero tras la puesta en marcha de nuevos protocolos para evaluar la salud de los animales antes de su ingreso en el país.

La Secretaría de Salud de México ha emitido un aviso epidemiológico después de que el 17 de abril se confirmara el primer caso humano de miasis por gusano barrenador.

El primer caso es el de una mujer de 77 años de edad residente del municipio de Acacoyagua, en el estado de Chiapas (sur).

En noviembre de 2024 se detectó un caso en un bovino de origen extranjero en Catazajá, Chiapas. Desde entonces se han detectado 869 casos en animales: 487 en Chiapas, 249 en Tabasco, 116 en Campeche, 13 en Quintana Roo y 4 en Yucatán.

Estas advertencias de Estados Unidos se producen en medio de la estrategia de negociación de aranceles del presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump.

title: Trump Is Laying a Potentially Deadly Trap for the U.S. Auto Industry
content: Trump’s approach risks leaving U.S. automakers isolated and incapable of competing on their own merits as foreign companies bolt ahead.
resumen:
President Trump has created a Luddite trap for the American auto industry: His tariffs aim to protect it from foreign competition, while his domestic policies threaten to cut it off from innovation. The damage to our economy and national security could be profound.

The auto industry has been a cornerstone of America’s industrial power. U.S. automakers are falling behind in a global race for innovation in electrification, digitization and automation. China has made huge strides in producing next-generation vehicles, backed by billions in state subsidies. Tesla has led in battery and automation innovation, but the scale and quality of China’s manufacturing are putting America’s entire auto industry at risk.

In the early 1980s, an onslaught of low-priced, fuel-efficient and government-subsidized Japanese vehicles overwhelmed U.S. automakers, prompting President Ronald Reagan to negotiate temporary limits on Japanese auto imports.

The Trump strategy applies a 25 percent tax on imported vehicles and parts. Nearly 60 percent of parts in typical U.S.-made vehicles are imported. The cost to our auto industry, estimated at $108 billion, will fall hardest on smaller, more vulnerable companies. It has already led to layoffs.

By targeting Mexico, Germany and Japan, Mr. Trump will hurt the bottom lines of their automakers, leaving China with even less foreign competition.

Mr. Trump is also mounting an assault on American innovation, motivated by his aversion to electric vehicles and his desire to slash the size of government. Batteries will determine not only who wins the race to manufacture the cars of the future but also America’s ability to decarbonize and maintain a modern military.

Government tax incentives have helped us start to close the gap in producing batteries. In the first quarter of 2025 alone, companies canceled more than $6 billion in planned battery manufacturing projects, including a $1 billion factory in Georgia and a $1.2 billion factory in Arizona.

The administration has cut $7 billion from the Department of Defense’s R&D budget, frozen billions in grants and withheld funding from leading research universities. The National Science Foundation may be next.

Mr. Trump’s approach could force the American automobile into a death spiral.

First, focus on the most urgent threats, such as China’s dumping of heavily subsidized E.V.s in foreign markets. The United States should negotiate high, temporary tariffs on these E.V.s with allies and trading partners.

Second, the United States should recommit to supporting innovation in batteries and other technologies by offering more R&D funding, tax incentives for cutting-edge industries and certainty for businesses to invest.

Finally, we should onshore innovation by welcoming foreign investment and talent. In exchange, foreign companies should be required to share their technology and source auto parts locally.

Mr. Trump seems set on stifling innovation and alienating our allies with indiscriminate tariffs. The United States will need a new and vocal coalition of business executives, unions and politicians pushing for domestic innovation.

title: Northern exposure: How Canadians are feeling about America as tariffs and threats of a ‘51st state’ loom
content: Jake’s Landing and Metaline Falls are stops along the International Selkirk Loop, a 280-mile scenic byway that circles through North Idaho, Pend Oreille County in far northeast Washington and the ...
resumen:
A survey of 73 Canadian event planners released this month by Northstar Meetings Group revealed:
•	52% of those planners reported that they had cancelled events in the United States as a result of tensions sparked from tariffs or rhetoric from President Donald Trump.
•	12% said they weren’t sure yet if events would be cancelled.
•	57% of the Canadian event planners said they have stopped considering the United States as a location for future events as a result of American policies or rhetoric affecting Canada.
President Donald Trump reiterated his “51st state” comments Wednesday, saying that Canada would cease to exist without United States trade and “as a state, it works great.”
Alex Beaudoin, operations manager for Cantina del Centro restaurant in Nelson, British Columbia, expects to see more business from domestic tourism this year, as many Canadians choose not to visit the U.S.
Greg Dick, a Nelson resident, said he is certain the tariffs are going to affect the Canadian economy.
Joyce Moran, another Nelson resident, said she likes that Trump supports Christian values, is practical and is a businessman.
Mike Boyle, the radio announcer for the Spokane Chiefs, said that at recent hockey playoff games in Vancouver and Victoria, the crowds haven’t booed during “The Star-Spangled Banner,” but have been respectful and especially quiet, while they are much louder and more boisterous singing “O Canada.”
Tom Thomson, executive director of the Nelson Chamber of Commerce, said although it is a little early to know, there does not seem to be a decrease in tourists from the U.S., and Americans are “absolutely” still welcome.
Border crossings from Canada are down significantly to rates not seen since the COVID-19 pandemic, for the entire border as well as at rural crossings to Eastern Washington and North Idaho, according to data from the U.S. Department of Transportation.
Public Relations Director Kate Hudson said Canadians made up about 5% of visitor traffic last year, including 954 visitors from British Columbia.
In March 2024, the visitor center had 58 check-ins from Canada compared to 39 last month. And as of April 16, there had been nine check-ins this month compared to 18 by that point last year.
Justin Kobluk, president of WestCoast Entertainment that presents Best of Broadway at the First Interstate Center for the Arts, reported similar messages from ticket holders.
Rose Noble, president of Visit Spokane, said the organization will continue to track the situation and listen to the concerns of international travelers.
Jennifer Wujick, owner of The Falls Market in Metaline Falls, Washington, said it hasn’t had a transaction in six weeks from Canadians. Normally, Canadians make up about 10% of her business.
Lars Jacobson, owner of Jake’s Landing in Porthill, Idaho, said the business is down more than 50%.
Donna Molvik, Executive Director of the International Selkirk Loop, said she has heard anecdotal reports about Canadian travelers opting for domestic trips.
Tourism makes up a $1.5 billion industry in Spokane County and supports almost 18,000 jobs, according to an economic impact report by Tourism Economics.

title: Una economía resiliente
content: La economía mundial vive tiempos turbulentos; pero nuestra economía está en posición de resistirlos.
resumen: La economía mundial vive tiempos turbulentos, pero la economía de Guatemala está en posición de resistirlos. La imposición de nuevos aranceles a escala global está dejando sentir sus efectos: desaceleración del comercio internacional, tensiones inflacionarias y un aumento de la incertidumbre económica, según informes de la Organización Mundial del Comercio y del Banco Mundial. Guatemala sentirá los coletazos de esta guerra comercial mundial, afectando las exportaciones por el arancel del 10% impuesto por el gobierno de Trump, así como por los menores volúmenes de comercio y cambios en los precios internacionales. Las remesas familiares podrían verse ralentizadas si el crecimiento económico de EE. UU. se desacelera; y las presiones inflacionarias podrían contagiarse a Guatemala. Se demanda una respuesta urgente por parte del gobierno y de los exportadores guatemaltecos, incluyendo negociaciones directas con el gobierno estadounidense y acciones para corregir las reglas, procedimientos, prácticas y protocolos que, según dicho gobierno, nuestro país aplica deslealmente en perjuicio de sus exportaciones. Guatemala tiene mejores herramientas para resistir los embates externos. El crecimiento económico ha sido sólido y estable —un promedio cercano al 3.5% anual en los últimos 20 años—. La política fiscal ha mantenido disciplina suficiente para evitar déficits insostenibles y niveles de endeudamiento preocupantes. La política monetaria, bajo la tutela de un banco central autónomo, ha sido ortodoxa y eficaz para mantener una inflación moderada y un tipo de cambio estable. La resiliencia de la balanza de pagos —respaldada por un superávit corriente y robustas reservas monetarias internacionales— fortalece aún más la capacidad de absorber choques externos. El Fondo Monetario Internacional ha reafirmado recientemente que la resiliencia de Guatemala no es casualidad: es el resultado acumulado de décadas de prudencia macroeconómica.

title: El tema arancelario genera tensión entre Estados Unidos y RD
content: Impuestos al arroz y lácteos estadounidenses han sido temas de discusiónLas licencias de importación provocan fricciones ...
resumen:
El tema arancelario genera tensión entre Estados Unidos y República Dominicana.

El Informe de Barreras Comerciales Extranjeras 2025 de la Oficina del Representante Comercial de los Estados Unidos (USTR) analiza las medidas que obstaculizan el acceso de bienes y servicios estadounidenses a mercados internacionales.

El DR-Cafta, firmado en 2004 e implementado progresivamente desde 2006, ha sido clave para el comercio dominico-estadounidense.

El Gobierno dominicano emitió el Decreto 693-24, que congela el cupo libre de aranceles para el arroz estadounidense en 23,300 toneladas métricas anuales, imponiendo un arancel del 99 % sobre el excedente.

Estados Unidos puso aranceles a productos procedentes de otros país, incluyendo un 10 % a los de origen dominicano.

Las exportaciones dominicanas también enfrentan un arancel del 10 % al ingresar a territorio estadounidense.

En Washington, D.C., se celebró una nueva ronda de negociaciones bilaterales entre representantes comerciales de ambos países.

El informe también denuncia que productos estadounidenses como el etanol y los quesos enfrentan cargas impositivas desiguales frente a sus homólogos locales.

En el caso del acero de refuerzo estadounidense (rebar), se exige un proceso de pruebas en laboratorios externos, procedimiento no requerido para la producción local.

El sistema de licencias de importación continúa siendo una fuente de fricción.

En cuanto a las compras gubernamentales, se han dado pasos hacia mayor transparencia con el nuevo reglamento aprobado en 2023, pero la ley que debía consolidar dichas reformas no fue aprobada por el Congreso y venció en enero de este año.

El Departamento de Trabajo de EE. UU. ha reportado desde 2013 deficiencias persistentes en materia de condiciones de trabajo, pago, vivienda y documentación de trabajadores extranjeros en el sector azucarero.

La delegación dominicana, encabezada por los ministros Víctor -Ito– Bisonó (Industria, Comercio y Mipymes), Roberto Álvarez (Relaciones Exteriores) y José Manuel Vicente (Hacienda), viajó a Washington la semana pasada para dialogar con autoridades de EE. UU. sobre disposición arancelaria global anunciada por la administración Trump.

La República Dominicana fue retirada en 2024 de la lista de vigilancia del informe Special 301.
